author: Anthony Morris

text:
@Anthony Morris  Part of what I study as a researcher is how people misjudge  what is true or effective in various fields, and one fascinating reason we get fooled is by choosing the wrong data. A second key reason is we don't interpret well the data we have--and we often misinterpret data because we lack other data that could have helped us see the bigger picture. 

For example, if you choose US wildfire data for the last 100 years, you immediately see the wildfires used to burn FAR more acres in the late 1920s through 1940s than they do now. Using that data, many people note that US wildfires are down dramatically over the past, so they  concluded that there's no reason for us to worry that man-made global warming will or has increased wildfires. 

There are a few problems with that line of reasoning, and they are big problems. First, the sky-high heat waves, droughts, and wildfires in the US in the late 1920s-1940s were not "normal conditions" for the US, they were of the by-product of dumb farming methods that created perhaps the worst man-made ecological disaster of the past--the Dust Bowl. Hundreds of millions of acres of land were tilled, leaving bare ground that lost its ability to retain moisture, resist drought, and support life. Ground that is bare can get up to 20-25 degrees F hotter in the summer than would ground that is covered with lush vegetation, so the hotter and drier conditions created local climate change in the west that was perfect for massive forest fires. Second, as more people started living in remote areas of the west, government got more serious about trying to put out forest fires. Third, as firefighting methods improved, even when fires broke out, we contained them faster and they burned fewer acres than they would have back in the 1930s. Thus, comparing wildfire acreage burned in the U.S. in the 1930s to the 2010s or 2020s is like comparing apples to watermelons--comparing acreage burned during a massive ecological disaster which made fires worse AND when we cared less about fighting fires and had less capacity to fight them to a later age when all those  conditions have changed. 

Thus, knowing that, and knowing most global warming occurred in recent decades, lets ask a more sensible question of the data. What are the trends in acreage burned after we cared more about fighting fires and had better technology to fight them (and weren't in the middle of the Dust Bowl)? Asking that question, acreage burned was pretty constant on average from the mid 1950s to the mid 1990s, but then it starts ramping up dramatically when the effects of global warming start kicking in. Back in the 1980s and 1990s, there was some "greening effect" from CO2 fertilization, but for the last 20 years, the hotter and drier conditions caused by higher CO2 levels has caused an increasing trend of global browning. Hotter and drier vegetation burns more easily, so wildfires are ramping up (also hotter drier conditions spawn more lightning strikes and make even pretty normal human activity more likely to trigger wildfires). 

"Yet the temp graph doesn't even come close to these graphs. We've used more fossil fuels in the last 20 years than in the entire period prior. From 1900 until 2016 (the peak) temps have risen barely 1.5 degrees. From 1930 until 2020 it is almost completely flat." Hmm, not sure what data you are looking at, but over the last 400,000 years, global temps and CO2 levels have tracked each other very closely. 

https://duckduckgo.com/?q=chart+of+CO2+and+temperatures&atb=v131-1&iax=images&ia=images&iai=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.johnenglander.net%2Fwp%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2F2011%2F07%2FCO2-Temperature%2520420%2520kyr.gif

All other things (orbital cycles, solar activity)  being equal, CO2 levels are the main control knob influencing global temps--albeit in part by increasing water vapor. 

From 1880 to now, CO2 levels and global temps have also tracked closely:

https://duckduckgo.com/?q=chart+of+CO2+and+temperatures&atb=v131-1&iax=images&ia=images&iai=http%3A%2F%2Fassets.climatecentral.org%2Fimages%2Fuploads%2Fgallery%2F2017EarthDay_TempAndCO2_en_title_lg.jpg

Also see https://climate.nasa.gov/news/2912/satellite-data-record-shows-climate-changes-impact-on-fires/

https://climate.nasa.gov/blog/3066/the-climate-connections-of-a-record-fire-year-in-the-us-west/

Take care.
author: Karl Wheatley

author: Anthony Morris

text:
​ @Anthony Morris  Thanks for your reply. 
I'll do this in pieces, so as to be more manageable for both of us. 

"There are also around 7.5 times the amount of people today so natural disasters are seemingly more frightening." OK, we agree on that, and of course they get more widely reported as well. But the fact a disaster affects more people now means it now takes a bigger chunk of personal and national budgets to prevent and repair the effects of such disasters.

"My burn acreage statement was to illustrate how effective we've become at dealing with fires." Sure, but the problem is that despite ever-improving fire-fighting methods, the acres burned are rising again--and are doing so when we have more at stake in those areas not burning. Larger fires also represent a reinforcing feedback loop for man-made global warming, releasing massive amounts of CO2. 

Another difference between disasters now and those in the 20th century is that prior to ~1970, the Earth could heal itself faster than we were withdrawing resources and damaging it. Since 1970, the rate of damage has increasingly outpaced the rate of regeneration and healing, and our current footprint is now ~175% of the annual carrying capacity of the Earth. So, just as someone who has declining health and reduced resilience is knocked more for a loop by an illness, when there is a bad drought or destructive hurricane, that is a bigger blow now, one that is pushing ecosystems closer to collapse. For example, due to hotter and drier conditions caused by our GG emissions, in some places after a forest fire these days (e.g., parts of the Sierra Nevada range) , the forest hasn't been regrowing as a forest, but as scrubland. This represents  ratcheting closer to collapse because scrubland sequesters less CO2 and water, and supports less biodiversity.  

"Hurricanes, droughts and floods are not getting worse." Floods are a mixed bag because air that is 1º C warmer can hold around 7% more moisture, so many places on Earth are getting drier but when the skies do open, they have and will often drop record-breaking precipitation--and the warmer it gets, the stronger both effects will become. So the total number of floods may not increase but some of the flooding will be almost "biblical." 

As for droughts, it is clear they are starting to get worse and IPCC correctly and confidently predicts increased drought overall (with the caveat that due to climate disruption and changing location of the jetstream, some places that have been historically dry will get more rain). More water up in the air means less down hear where we need it, those are just the laws of physics. You can see this gradual trend in the last 20 years, as the degree of water deficit to surplus across a decade has tipped significantly to the deficit side in places like Australia and the American West. 

https://www.discovermagazine.com/environment/drought-in-the-western-united-states-sets-a-122-year-record   

Unlike past drought cycles--which resolve themselves when the natural cycles/orbits tip the other way--these droughts will keep getting worse on average as more and more warming puts more and more moisture up in the sky. Thus, unless we fix it--and rapidly--it is a one-way ratchet effect, unlike anything modern civilization has lived through. 

Hurricanes: Cat 4 and 5 hurricanes have become markedly more common in the last 20 years, even compared to earlier decades when we had good satellite data. If you don't believe me, look up all the CAT 4 and CAT 5 hurricanes by decade, and count them as I have. Hotter oceans put more energy into hurricanes. There are three other documented changes in hurricanes: 1) They are intensifying faster, 2) They are stalling in one place longer (e.g., over the poor Bahamas), and 3) They are breaking down more slowly after landfall--this causing more intense damage inland. Again. more heat energy in the system allows for more powerful storms and helps them stay strong.  
 
"Prematurely introducing energy that is expensive and unreliable could have a greater dire effect on human flourishing than the consequences of climate change." 
Even without accounting for the trillions of dollars of externalized costs shifted to future generations by burning fossil fuels,  renewables are already as cheap or cheaper than FFs in many places, and as we ramp them up--and perhaps shift subsidies from deadly fossil fuels to less destructive renewables, the price advantage for renewables will just keep getting larger. So-called "green energy" also employs far more people in places like the US than FFs do. 

Even the hedge funds and big banks have pointed out we are well past they point where it would be cheaper in the long run to rapidly transition. As the saying goes, an ounce of prevention costs less than a pound of cure. 

Speaking of the costs of dealing with the problems humans have set in motion, Houston is eyeing a $26 billion system to protect themselves from storm surges. It will take $100 million a year to maintain, there's no guarantee it would work, and the way hydrology works, if you hold back the surge in one place, it just makes the flooding worse next door. 

As for the Dutch, when they raise their dikes 1 m, they have to make them 10 m wider to maintain the same structural integrity. Evidence from Earth's past indicates that if we leave the Earth at 400-450 ppm CO2, we can expect 30+ feet of eventual sea level rise. So the Dutch would have to make those dikes at least a football field wider across their entire length than they are now--and the costs for each additional meter increase in height keep rising, taking more and more out of national budgets. This same dynamic applies to heat waves, droughts, crop failures, etc. 

Whether it's human health, a car repair, or ecosystems, it's cheaper to fix the underlying cause as soon as possible rather than to pay to treat symptoms for years or decades, and THEN fix the underlying causes after the root cause of the problem has grown much larger in size.  

More later.
author: Karl Wheatley

text:
@Anthony Morris  A few more thoughts on your comments:

"One of the most proven methods to keep us safe from every single threat imaginable is wealth and prosperity. This is also under attack." Yes in one way and no in two ways. 

First no. When we in wealthy countries (I'm American) have created more wealth/grown the economy, being richer did put us wealthy folks in the position where we could afford to buy the things that protected us in the short-term from various threats (hunger, heat waves, etc.). 

However, wealth for wealthy nations has always been created through a process of legalized theft in which the billions of people in poorer nations are underpaid for their labor and natural resources. The "haves" had many mechanisms for carrying out this legalized theft, including land enclosures, slavery, gunboat diplomacy, hijacking other countries governments and installing folks favorable to pro-America and pro-capitalist policies, and tricking other countries into debt bondage (See Killing Hope and Confessions of an Economic Hit Man for a summary of some of this--and notice how the US is meddling in Venezuela and Bolivia and spreading propaganda about both... because we want Venezuela's oil and Bolivia's lithium). In the process, people in nations in the "global south" became less secure, their governments became increasingly dysfunctional, and their ecosystems were plundered. Thus, wealth creation made some people more secure by making others less secure.  

Second no. Creating cash wealth almost always involves more destruction of Earth's ecosystems via ecosystems disruption/destruction, pollution, killing species directly, and increased global warming. Put differently, growing the private sector economy larger has always involved shrinking the Earth economy that is the basis for all life on Earth, for our civilization--and for the private sector economy. Given that all these forces are already pushing ecosystems down the path towards collapse, you are buying a temporary boost in security by making worse the problem you are trying to protect yourself from. Continuing economic growth is incompatible with keeping ecosystems intact and able to support us because that money almost always involves further destruction of the web of life. Thus, trying to solve our ecological threats by growing the economy is like paying off your credit card debt using a credit card with a higher interest rate. For a different analogy, given that the private sector economy has a parasitic relationship with the Earth economy, growing the private sector economy larger and larger and larger is like the cancer getting bigger and bigger and eventually killing off the host organism on which it depends. Thus, we simply have to transcend that way of thinking whereby we think continued growth is possible or a good thing.

"The Netherlands has the ability to keep the Dutch safe. Bangladesh, not so much."
Given that the ecological problems facing the poorer countries were primarily caused by richer countries, we richer countries have a moral obligation to help fix the ecological problems we created and protect poorer countries from the monsters we are unleashing. From  scientific and self-preservation perspectives, there is simply no way to avoid ecological collapse unless wealth is more broadly spread across the world.  That is, the challenges we face are so massive and urgent, we can no longer afford to have people or governments anywhere who are so poor they can't afford the greener approaches and are tempted by the dirtier ones (coal-fired power plants). 

 "I see fossil fuels like I see vaccines. A cost benefit analysis demonstrates that the positives far out way the negatives." From a long-term perspective, the benefits of phasing out fossil fuels outweigh the costs by a factor of a thousand to one, or perhaps a million to one (or even an infinite ratio), especially given that continuing to burn fossil fuels risks runaway global warming and mass extinctions of life. If you haven't studied the science and listen to unqualified folks like Bjorn Lomborg, you might be under the impression that a world 3-4 degrees C warmer would be just fine, but in fact much of the world would be unlivable at the point, and we would then have a very hard time avoiding 5-6 degrees of warming, and extinctions on a mass scale. 
Let's remember that the last 5 times CO2 levels on earth spiked, mass extinctions occurred. Just sayin'.

Take care.
author: Karl Wheatley

text:
@Karl Wheatley   Wow, I have never witnessed someone's authenticity implode so thoroughly. What a tragic and exasperating way to end this conversation. While I disagreed with many of your views and assertions on climate change, I at least respected your approach and analysis. With this last "opinion" based sociological diatribe your credibility and my interest in your views has swiftly evaporated. For me, this ideological disposition exposes your climate beliefs as being purely ideologically driven. You never cared about the science, it has always been about ideology. With one single post you have solidified all my beliefs about climate change and this dangerous movement.  

I would honestly love nothing more than to address every single point, and objectively discredit them. The flaws made my head spin. Alas there is so much here to unpack it would take me all night. Experience also tells me this endeavor is futile with ideologically driven people. Suffice it to say I unequivocally reject these views. 

It is continuously confirmed that the climate movement is the domain of the Left. You proved it beyond a doubt. This fact alone is a serious red flag and contributes to the movement's growing lack of credibility and validates my growing skepticism. 

The climate movement is not an environmental movement at all. It is an ideological movement that is anti capitalist, anti industrialization, anti West, and quite frankly anti human and anti science. The earth is not some kind of pristine place that humans, like a parasite are wrecking. The earth is a hostile place that will kill you. Humans however, have made it more livable and safer with every passing century. This will undoubtedly continue. There is always going to be a price to pay to avoid living in a mud hut. I prefer to side with rational, objective people who embrace vision and courage over fear and hysteria. 

Most importantly, at this time I'll remind myself how fortunate I am to live in a Western society that embraces democratic principles like free and fair elections, freedom, liberty, a free press, free speech, human rights, property rights, secular government, rule of law, a separate judiciary and capitalism. The roadmap to wealth and prosperity that so many other cultures willfully reject, attack and bear the resulting suffering.
author: Anthony Morris

text:
@Anthony Morris  Thanks for your reply. "Wow, I have never witnessed someone's authenticity implode so thoroughly. What a tragic and exasperating way to end this conversation. While I disagreed with many of your views and assertions on climate change, I at least respected your approach and analysis." Implode? I offered a calm and careful analysis of our situation, including its causes, and its solutions. If I am understanding correctly, you have now responded so strongly because you disagree with my analysis, are unaccustomed to hearing these facts--and are personally bothered by them--and thus have lost interest in discussing the points. 

It is well-established empirically that expanding the economy causes more ecological destruction. It is also well-established empirically that the richest people and richest nations have caused and still cause the majority of ecological destruction. Those facts are not in dispute. Even greater energy efficiency just leads to more total consumption of energy, a phenomenon know as Jevons' Paradox. Thus, when we as consumers have the experience that more economic growth, more economic development or more personal wealth solves some of our short-term personal problems, the creation of that wealth/growth/ development simultaneously caused more    ecological destruction. 

"Most importantly, at this time I'll remind myself how fortunate I am to live in a Western society that embraces democratic principles like free and fair elections, freedom, liberty, a free press, free speech, human rights, property rights, secular government, rule of law, a separate judiciary ..." All of that refers to a representative democracy/constitutional republic, and has nothing to do with capitalism in general nor the the form of winner-take-all capitalism that has hijacked our democracy over the last 40 years.  It is also well-established that when too much wealth gets concentrated in too few hands, that corrodes and then destroys democracy. 

“Corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places will follow, and the money-power of the country will endeavor to prolong its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is aggregated in few hands and the republic is destroyed.”   
- Abraham Lincoln

Or, as former U.S. Supreme Court justice Louis Brandeis put it: 

 “You can have wealth concentrated in a few hands, or you can have democracy, but you can’t have both.”

History shows that highly concentrated wealth causes governments to become corrupted and collapse (see Jared Diamond's work) but economic history demonstrates that unless checked by powerful counterbalancing forces, capitalism concentrates more and more wealth in fewer and fewer hands (see Piketty's research--or just the last 20 years in the US). That growing inequality spells the death of both democracy and also turns out to be deadly for ecosystems. It also demoralizes the 99% and leads to exactly the kind of fraying of the social fabric we are seeing in America today. To have a healthy society, wealth HAS TO be distributed much more equally than in the U.S. (See the research in The Spirit Level). 

"The roadmap to wealth and prosperity that so many other cultures willfully reject, attack and bear the resulting suffering." 

I'm not sure quite who you have in mind, but I'm just spelling out the laws of nature:   Growth in the private sector economy has always been created by exploiting and degrading the Earth economy--the latter being the foundational economy for all life on Earth. In fact, if you subtract the costs to repair the ecological degradation caused by various sectors of the economy, no sector and virtually no companies are left with any net profit. 

Similarly, economic growth has always been accompanied by and made possible by exploiting other people and nations. I love America in many ways, but do you have any idea how many countries we have meddled with, how many governments we have bullied and overthrown so as to enhance our corporations' bottom line and expand so-called free-market capitalism? 

All that may be a harsh reality to have to face after the fairy tales that Milton Friedman or the Wall Street Journal or Fox News have told us, but it's still the truth. 

Capitalism has always been a looting mechanism: Could we have possibly built the financial empire we built in the U.S. without stealing an entire land mass from the Native Americans, enslaving Africans for centuries, and looting the raw materials of other nations via gunboat diplomacy? Of course not--America as we know it simply wouldn't exist: Hell, the slaves even built much of the White House, the Washington Monument, the southern railroads and so on.   Read a little history to learn how the UK exploited and cheated India to get their own textile industry going and even taxed the salt on India's own land just to grow their own empire. 

But the broader and more important point is that the core goals, values, and principles of industrialized capitalism and consumerist lifestyles are flatly incompatible with meeting the needs of everyone and with avoiding ecological collapse. Just to avoid ecological collapse will require shrinking the footprint of the global economy by ~50% and it never growing again. We can partly decouple GDP from footprint, but only partly, so than means once GDP and our corresponding footprint gets above a  certain size, the economy must stop growing our ecosystems, our civilization, and our population will all collapse. 

Sorry, those are just the laws of nature--I know that's a rude awakening given that we have been living according to all sorts of fairy tales about endless growth and progress. 

Take care.
author: Karl Wheatley

text:
@Anthony Morris  "The climate movement is not an environmental movement at all." Of course it is: If we don't stop man-made global warming, Earth's ecosystems will steadily become more degraded and then collapse. Half the world's previous coral reefs are now dead due to man made global warming, the permafrost is collapsing in places, and forest from the Rockies to Siberia, the Amazon and elsewhere  have declining health due to man-made global warming. Species extinctions and crop failures are up due to global warming (with help from pollution and ecosystem destruction). This is about saving all the life on earth we can still save. 

"It is continuously confirmed that the climate movement is the domain of the Left." You are entitled to your opinions but you are not entitled to your own facts. Back in the 1980s, and parts of the 1990s and even 2000s, leading GOP figures openly admitted that man0made global warming was going on and we had to do something about it. They are on videotape saying as much. Then their wealthy campaign donors--especially fossil fuel companies got very unhappy with them and suddenly GOP candidates did an about-face and started toeing the Exxon/Mobil company line (and saying some truly nutty and unscientific things about global warming).  At the same time, billionaires and oil companies started dumping up to $200 million a year to spread climate disinformation--sheer corporate propaganda that is easily disproven by the sound science. But clever propaganda works, and now you are repeating back to me some of the talking points from that expensive propaganda campaign. Do you realize that the GOP is the only major conservative party on Earth still engaging in pretending that man-made global warming isn't real and dangerous? 

Sorry, but there outside of the GOP echo chambers and in the real world of science, there is a solid chain of evidence PROVING human activity caused ~100% of net global warming over the 1880-2020 time span, all the major predictions of the theory of man-made global warming have come true, and 14 different climate models, some dating back to the 1970s and 1980s--have accurately predicted how much our emissions would warm the Earth. That debate is over among all but the most ideologically-blinkered climate scientists (e.g., the scientists who work for oil companies).



"I prefer to side with rational, objective people who embrace vision and courage over fear and hysteria." I have vision and I have courage, but if you aren't scared about what we are doing to the Earth, you don't know the science. We have already destroyed half of Earth's biomass, including half the forests, more than half the marine life, and more than half the wild mammals. As Earth's biomass goes down, it can support fewer and fewer of us--and at lower and lower standards of living. So if you want to avoid the mud hut--and I sure do--you leap into action to bring human's collective footprint within the limits of Earth's carrying capacity. Our predicament is much like a family who has a million dollars in the bank, and we make $100K a year but we are spending $175K a year--the faster we bring our spending in line with out income, the more principal we can preserve. The longer we keep living beyond our/earth's limits, the closer we come to bankruptcy/ecological collapse. 

The path we are on now leads to  a massive ecological collapse--this is well understood among scientists, and in fact, they have been issuing warnings about this since the early 1990s. Plankton populations are down 40% since the 1950s, insects and bird populations are down sharply, the rates of amphibian extinctions have been astronomical, in some places 99% of green sea turtles are being born female due to global warming, the Earth shifted from a brief period of global greening due to more CO2 to a global browning trend due to hotter and drier conditions starting around 2000. Dead zones in the oceans now numbers in the hundreds, and oxygen levels are starting to drop in the oceans, etc. etc. 

Sorry my friend, but those are the facts on the ground. In physics, actions have consequences, so when you increase the level of something called "greenhouse gases" by 50%, it gets warmer. In life science, actions have consequences, so when you churn out endless chemical and plastic pollutants, destroy most natural habitat, and rapidly make the Earth warmer than it has been for tens of thousands of years, things unaccustomed to hotter and drier conditions die. Lots of things.

text:
The AGW anthropogenic global warming hypothesis and the alleged Greenhouse Gas Hypothesis are in the same category with the Fake Space Programme. Money is calling all the shots. Scam after scam after scam. Some one some where is making a lot of money out of all of this silliness. 

IS SPACE TRAVEL REALLY POSSIBLE ? This question might appear to be a million light years away from the subject of VAMPIRES and other such GOTH things. However, I have heard it said that aliens might be vampires, coming from outer space, to attack the Earth, so as to be turning us humans into captive farm animals, for the harvesting of our ADRENOCHROME. This, believe it or not, is what certain UFO enthusiasts, at MUFON, have been saying. Such a point of view is probably coming from the, counter intelligence propaganda machine, so as to increase government spending, on the military hardware, where by so as to thwart the perceived alien threat. Before his death, earlier this year in 2018, Professor Stephen Hawking, spoke out about the possibility of such an alien invasion. But, I want to add my point of view to all of this speculation about aliens. In my opinion, material space travel is 100% not possible. Therefore in my opinion we have absolutely nothing to worry about. How can I be so sure that material space travel is 100% not possible ?

First, the sheer DISTANCE involved is a major problem confronting anyone wanting to go anywhere in space. The Universe is extraordinarily vast. Even the nearest star to our own, ALPHA CENTAURUS, is nothing less than four light years away. A very bright star, ALPHA CANIS MAJOR, SIRIUS, "The Dog Star", which we in the Northern Hemisphere can see in the southern horizon during winter nights, is no less than six light years away. Light travels at 300,000 kilometres per second, which translates as 186,000 miles per second. Utterly massive distances. Just the central hub of our MILKYWAY Galaxy measures 100,000 light years diameter. The full diameter of our MILKYWAY GALAXY spiral arms, is nothing less than 1,000,000 light years. The nearest major Galaxy to our own, is the ANDROMEDA Galaxy, and it is 22,000,000 light years away from us. Visible in the Northern Hemisphere, it measures eleven lunar diameters in the sky. Beyond that, there exist unlimited numbers of other galaxies, in all directions, stretching out to infinity. Any kind of space ship, capable of supporting such a journey, would be impossible. Simply 100% not possible. Food, water, air, fuel ? Getting it into space ?

Secondly, there is the problem of RADIATION. Any such space ship would have to possess a massive shield hull, with in which would be our habitation hull, with all the air, water, food and fuel. We only have to go beyond, low earth orbit, to run into such deadly solar radiations from the Sun, as well as cosmic radiations from our galaxy, and other galaxies too. Just beyond low earth orbit we encounter the Van Allen Radiation Belts.

Thirdly, there is the engineering reality that ROCKET PROPULSION DOES NOT WORK IN SPACE like as the science fiction industry would have us all believe. Only believe to be the truth, that which has been proven to be the truth, by the scientific method. The problem of propelling a space ship is in the fact that space is a perfect vacuum. Thus the rocket has nothing to push against. Propulsion requires that there be, DISPLACEMENT OF INTRINSIC MASS, equal to, or greater than, the intrinsic mass of the ship, being propelled. Ships on the water, have propellers that displace the weight of the ship, in water. The ship is displacing its own weight, in water, thus it floats on the surface of that water. Submarines, are also displacing their own weight, in water, thus, so as to be able to go up and down in that water. Aircraft have propellers or jet turbines that do the same, by displacing the air, equal to the weight of the aircraft. Then, as the aircraft begins levitating down the runway, the wings are producing a down draft of air, behind the aircraft. Thus, displacing air, equal to the weight of the aircraft, and thus the aircraft begins lifting off of the ground. A rocket spaceship, launching into the sky, is displacing its own weight in air, and thus it begins to float up into the sky. As it climbs upwards, the air, that was at its most dense at sea level, begins to get thinner. So that the efficiency of the rocket, gets less and less, until we are confronted by the vacuum of space, where in the efficiency of the rocket becomes, zero. Rockets only propel because of air displacement. Once in the vacuum of space, there is zero air displacement. So I have no hesitation in stating that, according to real science, rocket propulsion is 100% not possible in space. No air displacement, therefore no propulsion.

So, we are confronted by the realisation that the space programme is a scam. 100% FAKE ! This might not be obvious to most people, but it is crystal clear, to me. No one has, or ever will be, walking on the Moon. Going to Mars is utterly not possible. There are no rovers on Mars. No probes exploring the outer solar system. NASA is a huge scam. Over the years, since its founding by President Eisenhower and then with President Kennedy, in the 60's, they have improved on their ability to produce fake images, using cinematic tricks and nowadays high end, expensive CGI, which then feeds into the cinema industry and computer games. text:
You can not meassure the average temperature of this planet by using thermometers. Especialy the scientific ones. 70% of the earth's surface is covered by oceans, hardly any scientific gauge to find there. In Europe there are over 2900 thermometers in use for this, but on Antarctica (roughly the same size as Europe) only . . . 8 (yes, eight that is).
Measuring the earths avarage temperature this way is garbage.
How about what science think of temperatures of the past? Well in those cases they use sourses like the remains of coral in the oceans, pollen of plants on land etc., all of them leaving traces over time that are less influenced by short term rizes and falls of temperatures and react more on what globaly is going on. Still not very presize but far more secure then gauges.
Drawback is that with such methods we only know the temperature of decades or longer ago, not of last years.

text: Otosj, have you heard of the Argo float project?  There are nearly 4,000 autonomous floats that cover the major oceans, measuring temperature and salinity.  The floats move between the surface and around 2000m collecting data, and transmit the results via satellite to the operations centre every 10 days.  So ocean temperatures are indeed monitored, and the data is publicly available.  You can learn more at https://argo.ucsd.edu/

text:
@Paul W  The temperature data is accurate, no doubt about that. The point is what conclusions that people want to draw from them.
First, the only temperature changes that take place according to climate change are roughly limmited to heights up to 3000 meters above sealevel. And they are not everywhere the same. It is an avarage. And there is the first problem, weather you support the data or not, avarages are calculable, but that is only a mathematical excercise. 
Example:
Suppose I own 3 houses, one with only 1 room, the other with 2 rooms and the third with 3 rooms. I have equaly many houses with 1 room as I have with 2 rooms as I have with 3 rooms. But the avarage mathematics dictates that I sum up all of the rooms (1+2+3=6) and divede them over the amount of houses I have (3 houses), and voilá: I have an avarage of 2 houses. But tha avarage tells us nothing. I someone would ask me, knowing I own 3 houses what the avarage amount of rooms I have this person will think I own more then one house with 2 rooms as the majority of people uses "avarage" asbeing the most of them.
Secondly, where in this 3000 meters of height do you want to place your temperature measurement equipement? Sealevel? Well, seawater likes to hold temperatures constant, so there is a chance you miss the higher (or lower) temperature changes that take place in for example to 100 meters high, or at 900 meters high.
And so on.

This is not my fantasy, it is what I have learned when I became an engineer; do not trust data only!! You must also know what its context is. How was the data collected.
Mind; there still is nothing wrong with the data itself.
Here another one: 
In my country politicians do not talk about the avarage income, but of the modulair income: as we have a high number of true millionaires, the avarage income is quite high. The majority of people would have the impression that they are pretty poor.
So instead politicians use modulair income, the income the majority of the people have, which is lower. So, far less people feel poor and everybody is happy. 
(This is not a political statement but an explanation about how numbers work.)

I am not a mathamatician, I am an engineer. I build ships. And those things work best if they stay straight up more or less. And here you have it: about everything an board there is exact data to be found, but does it help you to draw the right conclusion?!

Sorry for this long reply, and skipping the requested websites. I visited so many over the years that it is hard to make a choice out of them.
author: Otosj van Tolerbok

text:
@Otosj van Tolerbok  What a reply!  It looks like you are concerned about the average or Global Mean Temperature.  I really have not questioned this aspect of the science, as I have not seen many criticisms, other than the simplistic “the global mean temperature does not exist”, or from the handful of people who think the government meteorological agencies are conspiring to ‘fix’ the temperature records to show warming.  I believe that the global average is a weighted one, so hopefully it is not as problematic as the one in your example.

You mention “modulair income” – is that median income, or something else?  The median seems to me to be a better measure, particularly when contrasted with the average.  Perhaps “modulair” is the median?

text:
I don't know if any of you eco warriors noticed but this "scientist" fellow stumped himself. He said that carbon dioxide is evenly spread throughout the atmosphere, and that there was variability globally in terms of temperature and the figure given for the cooling was a global average. He stopped talking after that (formed an incomplete question and literally stopped). This is the problem. Carbon dioxide is spread evenly throughout the atmosphere. There are variations even at identical latitudes. Carbon dioxide levels don't explain the variability. 
There are papers on pub med that inadvertently bring up the real drivers for climate change. The biggest contributing factors to climate change are - Solar Activity and Geology (continental drift, volcanicity etc). Continental drift alters topographic relief of certain landmasses offer huge spans of time. This is why Scotland, for example, is full of old red sandstone. It used to be a hot desert. 
Solar activity is obviously a main driver because sunspot intensity and frequency determine how much heat reaches the planet. And volcanicity is another because only volcanic activity releases gasses on such a scale as to alter the composition of gases in the atmosphere to a significant degree in a short enough time to actually influence the climate. It also produces dust clouds which reflect or obscure light meaning heat doesn't reach the ground. This can result in cooling such as that which is thought to have wiped out the dinosaurs.

text: @John Wilson  actually I trained as one. I never pursued a career in research or education because there's no money in it. I decided instead to work in energy. So I do have some knowledge of the subject and without naming names I will say this. The 97% consensus is nonsense. In reality there isn't much of a consensus with respect to anthropogenic climate change. Some do "believe" in it. Others are skeptical. It's more like 50/50 when we consider the question properly. You see when Obama and the like (think "scientists" in the public eye, like Bill Nye - who is definitely not a real scientist, or Sir David Attenborough, who I believe is well intentioned but sadly has elected to jump on the climate change bandwagon because emotionally it has a greater impact - people generally don't give a shit about the natural world, but for some reason they seem to care about carbon dioxide emissions. It seems a convenient scapegoat and they are all for green technologies as long as consumerism isn't compromised. In reality it will take a lot more effort from everyone, including big companies in order to really have a genuinely positive impact on the ecological systems currently under actual threat. People only seem to care if the threat is pointed at humanity. It seems we are more species-ist than racist when it really comes down to it. Although ignorance is certainly the greater factor here, there is little positive to say about governments handling of these issues. The real problems of globalisation as it relates to environmental impact are largely hidden or only addressed using very few words. It seems that habitat destruction (which is a real and serious problem far worse than the impact of greenhouse gas emissions). What I mean by this is that the real threats are being glossed over with one that can be used to generate revenue. It's business as usual. The green energy industry is a cover thats not only worse than the fossil fuel problem in terms of direct emissions and environmental damage, it's also less efficient. Take for example Drax power station in the UK which moved to carbon neutral status with the change from coal to biomass. Biomass of course being wood chips. Wood chips from hardwood trees in Virginia. This is relatively old, stable forestry that's being destroyed to fire up a power station so that the UK can manage any dropout from the renewable energy (providing base load capacity and emergency additional capacity when renewables aren't producing enough to meet demand). This power station burns at present approximately 6 million tonnes of hardwood pellets per year. It's a false economy. This is happening everywhere that renewables are being used. The trees they cut down are part of a climax community. This is a stable and environmentally vital piece of woodland ecology. The destruction of habitat is catastrophic for biodiversity. But that's not the only issue. We know that cutting down forest destroys the soil environment and it becomes very difficult thereafter to plant trees in those areas. Fungal activity takes over, breaking down dead trees, this is often followed by disease in sapling trees and the new environment is generally less suitable for mature trees. There are many other impacts here. Also, with humanities tendencies to interfere with the environment we can't rule out the use of pesticides, herbicides and fungicides. Where trees are cut down and replanted we can almost guarantee that some kind of fertiliser will be used, possibly some kind of pesticides etc to ensure they grow relatively competition free. But this isn't the whole picture. Clearings left by felling are also more likely to be colonised by previously foreign plants and animals. This can alter soil conditions. It is also possible that GM crops from nearby fields would take advantage of that new source of natural light that wouldn't have penetrated the canopy of a mature forest. The implications and consequences are numerous and complex. Long story short, we shouldn't be interfering with these environments. Coal is also better suited to burning. It burns more efficiently and coal generates more energy per unit mass than wood of any kind. So why don't they just use the coal? They have coal here in the UK, it doesn't have to be boated across the Atlantic, local workers will have jobs. The environmental impact of burning coal locally is far lower than importing ecologically important hardwood, cutting it up, transporting it, drying it out and turning it into chips then loading it onto trains to simply be burned.
author: Walter White

text: @John Wilson  I can see what you're trying to insinuate. Why is it that anyone who speaks out against the glaringly obvious flaws of supposed green energy or renewables gets lumbered in with proponents of oil and gas? Why is it especially that anyone who works in energy that gets tarred with that brush? And why do you assume that just because someone works in oil and gas they are somehow biased toward that particular form of energy? To answer your question more clearly I work in energy in general. Oil and gas, wind, nuclear. I've never worked in solar or geothermal and I've done some work in the hydroelectric industry briefly as well. I don't see why that's relevant. In fact it's a straw man argument. You assume that my profession says something about me as a person. I suppose in many cases it probably does. But that's a generalisation and not a very accurate one at all in this case. And what sets my opinions apart from those of many others is that I've not only studied the science, and I mean actually studied it, I've also got real world experience. I know how these industries work. I know how their assets work. I've seen the environmental impact of all of them in the real world. Do yourself a favour, watch planet of the humans. It speaks on issues I've been aware of for a very long time. The problem with most people, and I'm including you here because you've said nothing of substance (only made vague and pathetic attempts to attack my character in a condescending and passive-agrressive manner), is that they parrot sentiments that they've picked up from the newspaper or An Inconvenient Truth. text: I am so sick and tired of hearing all of the BS about our planet warming. the cooling trend has already begun, from the past few solar cycles being extremely quiet compared to "normal". The lag in time from the affects of the solar cycles to be seen here on earth can take decades. So, since we are just beginning to see the cool down trend, i predict that it will continue to drop. this will not stop, it will continue to get cooler on average in many places on earth. If you ever want to know the upcoming weather of a season, just look back approximately 11 years (solar cycle) and the weather will be fairly similar. the intensity of the weather may be different than the last cycle, but the patterns will be very similar. the 2020-2021 winter has been very similar to 2009-2010. this past summer, was also extremely comparable to the summer of 2009.  so moving forward, if you live on the east coast, prepare for next winter (2021-2022) to be similar to 2010-2011.  the only differences i can see is that because our previous solar cycles were very inactive, the intensity will be stronger than the previous cycle. So be prepared for many nor'easters next winter, with the difference of more precipitation coming with those storms. Its so obvious if you look at the solar cycle graphs, and compare it to the weather you receive on these approx. 11 year cycles. Its not a perfect science, nothing is when we talk about weather, but it's a pretty darn good way to at least get a basic idea of the upcoming weather patterns by season.

text:
Easy Red.
When you see that fluctuations are in the past , then the correct analysis of the data is to do a spectral analysis, and take the dominant frequencies, reconstruct  the time history and compare it with the past , if it fits then you can extrapolate with more confidence than a simple linerar trend line. That has been done with the result that the superposition of just 2 periods explains the periodic trace over at least 200 years, including the apparent linear trent, we all argue about. Since the resulting spectrum does not correspond to a  continious spectrum of a straight line, you must rule out the validity of a linear data fitting.
That is the correct mathematical analysis.
The work was done by Prof. O. Weiss. Look it up.
In the analysis of the behaviour of the flexible structure of helicopters during and after hard landings,  that approach proved to be very accurate in order to identify the weak areas that needed to be improved.
author: Hernan Posnansky

text: @Hernan Posnansky  Familiar with Spectral Analysis...however there is dispute over its ability to correctly analyse the cyclical nature of weather with respect to unique impacts on the observable cycles of climate change. Working with a relatively 'simple' mechanical model of aerodynamics  of helicopter blades to support a statistical analysis of a much more complex modelling of climate may not be valid. So not sure that it adds or improves the understanding of climate change and the impact of human endeavours in accelerating that rate.......for the lay mathematical understanding the linear interpolation is as valid......
author: Red Terrier

text:
@Red Terrier  
Please do not missunderstand me.
All I am saying is that this is the correct way to do the curve fitting, a pure mathematical process, which gives higher confidence for extrapolation purposes, both slightly ahead in time and certainly in mathematicaly modelling the past.
Incidentally what I described does not include the details of avoiding pitfalls associated with the digital sampling of 'noisy' data, like aliasing below the Nyquist frequency ,etc.
But I am sure you know all this.
I never intended to make an analogy of helicopter vibrations to the weather.
The data involved in the helicopter post flight analysis are NOT statistic, but accurate measurements, both analog and sampled.
And you have resonances and aeroelastic blade flutter to content with, far from simple dynamics.
All I was trying to infer was that with the tools available like the CFFT, The spectral analysis is a powerful tool to understand the dynamics of cyclic processes. And the ability to recognize also the noncyclic elements that may also be present, like blade divergence in the case of the helicopter rotor.
author: Hernan Posnansky

text: @Hernan Posnansky  Points taken.

GRETA THUNBERG IS A SHILL FOR THE GREEN INDUSTRY AND THEIR GOVERNMENT AGENDA !
Not one prediction or model of any Climate Alarmist has come to fruition without manipulation of Historical Data
THE CLIMATE ALARMIST 97% LIE !!!!
The 97% statistic that all Climate Scientist agree Man is primarily responsible for Anthropogenic Global Warming first appeared in 2009 in a study by the University of Illinois master student Kendall Zimmerman and her advisor Peter Doran. It was a two-question survey and only 5% of the people who answered a little over 150 were actual Climate Scientists. The 97% comes from an even smaller sub-set of 79 people who were self-professed Climate Scientists with 50% of their research being conducted on the subject of Climate Change. So that 97% figure originally came from 79 Scientists who agreed that the Earth’s temperature has risen since the 1800s and that Humans are likely a contributing factor. People used this Number and ran with it. When the evidence was running a little thin and people started questioning it in 2013 Australian blogger John Cook and some of his buddies reviewed some abstracts of peer-reviewed papers published between 1991 to 2011. What were his findings?: Coincidently that exactly 97% of Scientists either explicitly or implicitly made the assertion that Humans were somewhat responsible for warming not even Climate Change, BUT WARMING, his work was debunked as CRAP in Science and Education I August 2013. For example, David R Legates ( a professor at the University of Delaware and former director of it’s Center for Climatic Research) and three coauthors reviewed the same papers as did Mr. Cook and found “ only 41 papers—0.3 percent of all 11,944 abstracts or 1.o percent of the 4,014 expressing an opinion, and not 97.1 percent--- had been found to endorse” the claim that human Activity is causing most of the current warming. Elsewhere, climate scientists including Craig Idso, Nicola Scafetta, Nir J. Shaviv and Nils-Axel Morner. Whose research questions the alleged consensus, protested that Mr. Cook ignored or misrepresented their work. Professor legates peered reviewed paper debunking Cook:

text:
GRETA THUNBERG IS A SHILL FOR THE GREEN INDUSTRY AND THEIR GOVERNMENT AGENDA !
Not one prediction or model of any Climate Alarmist has come to fruition without manipulation of Historical Data
THE CLIMATE ALARMIST 97% LIE !!!!
The 97% statistic that all Climate Scientist agree Man is primarily responsible for Anthropogenic Global Warming first appeared in 2009 in a study by the University of Illinois master student Kendall Zimmerman and her advisor Peter Doran. It was a two-question survey and only 5% of the people who answered a little over 150 were actual Climate Scientists. The 97% comes from an even smaller sub-set of 79 people who were self-professed Climate Scientists with 50% of their research being conducted on the subject of Climate Change. So that 97% figure originally came from 79 Scientists who agreed that the Earth’s temperature has risen since the 1800s and that Humans are likely a contributing factor. People used this Number and ran with it. When the evidence was running a little thin and people started questioning it in 2013 Australian blogger John Cook and some of his buddies reviewed some abstracts of peer-reviewed papers published between 1991 to 2011. What were his findings?: Coincidently that exactly 97% of Scientists either explicitly or implicitly made the assertion that Humans were somewhat responsible for warming not even Climate Change, BUT WARMING, his work was debunked as CRAP in Science and Education I August 2013. For example, David R Legates ( a professor at the University of Delaware and former director of it’s Center for Climatic Research) and three coauthors reviewed the same papers as did Mr. Cook and found “ only 41 papers—0.3 percent of all 11,944 abstracts or 1.o percent of the 4,014 expressing an opinion, and not 97.1 percent--- had been found to endorse” the claim that human Activity is causing most of the current warming. Elsewhere, climate scientists including Craig Idso, Nicola Scafetta, Nir J. Shaviv and Nils-Axel Morner. Whose research questions the alleged consensus, protested that Mr. Cook ignored or misrepresented their work. Professor legates peered reviewed paper debunking Cook:

text:
William Kininmonth knows what he is talking about. Except few people who have not studied climatology will understand what he is talking about or why it is important. Sad that some of the best scientists do not explain climate well. A couple additional graphs might have helped.
Basically, El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) produces as great a change in temperature during its short cycle of (5 to 7 years) as global climate change in periods of 30 to 60 years. That is because most of the Earth's heat from the Sun is stored in the tropical ocean and is only gradually mixed down to a depth of 1,000 or so meters (3300 feet or so), depending on geographic location and oceanic oscillations (currents).

The graph of the ocean temperature is hardly ever shown to the public. But it's the oceans that drive climate. The graphs like the one shown in the video that show land temperature tell us something about the average weather, but do not tell us much what the climate system is doing. 

We have to study the oceans to do that. And the Argo system of buoys that measure the ocean have not been deployed long enough to do that. By 2050 we ought to have enough information from these buoys to know with some certainty how the oceans drive the climate system.

Nevertheless, based on studies of changes in ocean heat content, the energy imbalance at the top of the atmosphere has been calculated as 0.5 Watt per square meter 0.5 Wm-2). (The night light in a child's nursry is about 5 watts. And an ordinary candle about one Watt.)  One Watt spread evenly across a one-meter surface does not produce enough temperature increase to be felt by bare hands.

The amount of sunlight reflected back into space without heating the Earth is about 102 Wm-2. About half, 51 Wm-2, is reflection from clouds back to outer space. If cloudiness has decreased by one per cent (1%) in the last 200 years, that would explain all of the climate change now attributed to Greenhouse gases. (But does not prove that variations in cloudiness are what causes the climate to change.)

The drivers of climate change operate so gently that they cannot be measured directly. The errors in the estimate of energy imbalance are big compared to the power of the drivers. Thus, we cannot measure either cooling or warming directly. The result is that climate changes so slowly that decades could pass before we could be sure whether long-term climate is warming or cooling.

Land and Sea temperature record compared
https://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/graphs_v4/graph_data/Temperature_Anomalies_over_Land_and_over_Ocean/graph.html

text: The climate changes because the climate changes. This is not a static system. Variables in cloud cover releases heat when cloud cover is sparse and traps heat when cloud cover is dense. What IS dense cloud cover and what IS sparse cloud cover and why is it not THE SAME all the time? That is why weather and climate change. Nearly three quarters of the earths surface is oceans and lakes that produce more water vapor into the atmosphere when the sky is clear and less when there is more cloud cover. The atmospheric water vapor we call clouds is at variable altitudes and the solar heat input to that is directly variable to the density of water vapor at altitude. The last I checked, water vapor is 100 times more efficient as a heat trap than CO2, and CO2 levels must DOUBLE to absorb 1 additional degree Celcius,  add to that the fact that only half of the planet is exposed to sunlight while half is in darkness called "night" when vast amounts of heat escapes into space from the upper atmosphere. There seems to be very little information as to how much heat escapes into space, but heat tends to move from hot to cold and I hear that space is VERY cold. The density of cloud cover is the driving force of climate.

Earth has had many warming periods in the geologic past that were much warmer than today. Man wasn't around back then, so how was man responsible for them? Can Greta explain the 40,000 year tilt cycle of Earth that goes from 22 1/2 degrees to 24 1/2 degrees and then back the other direction, or the 100,000 ( approximately, and it varies ) year cycle of Earth's orbit around the Sun that goes from maximum  elliptical in one direction away from the sun then back to circular, then maximum elliptical in the other direction?, then the approximate 26,000 year Precession of the Axis of Earth, and how each of these individual cycles influences Earth's climate then combine all three cycles and the many combinations of the three and explain how all of that influences our climate????? And this is just one aspect of the many other forces of planet Earth and of the many different solar events that influence our climate. And then we have underwater volcanic eruptions that heat the oceans and the El Nina & La Nino, the Gulf Stream currents, the jet streams...and other factors. text:
@D JG  And of course you can't look it up. As I said, global warming induces climate change, the latter entailing much more than a rise in global mean temperature. Just a few examples (this is NOT an exhaustive list!):
- ocean acidification --> affects the nature, but also the food chain and thus us!
- sea level rise --> threatens the civilization living along the coasts)
- more and stronger extreme events (droughts, heat waves, hurricanes, ...)
- glaciers melting --> affects our reservoirs of fresh water and of course the sea level
- affects the ecosystems (fast temporal changes!) and the animals that can't adapt fast enough
- and much more!

It's not that simple, is it?
author: Christophe Espic

text:
@Gary  Where does the cold come from?  Heat in the atmosphere. 
Calm down, uncross your eyes.  Unusual cold at odd times is due to the intrusion of cold air from the arctic.  (This is primarily a northern hemisphere effect).  Why is cold air moving south in larger amounts and at unusual times?  Because the temperature differential between equatorial regions and the Arctic is reduced as the Arctic is heating at two to as much as three times the rate as the lower latitudes.  Jennifer Francis predicted this effect as the Arctic jet stream is disrupted and distorted by weakening of the Hadley cells which assist in isolating air currents in regions of latitude.  The jet stream acted as a sort of wall against large amounts of mixing of hot, moist equatorial air and cold, dry Arctic air.  Their function depends on pressure differentials caused by differing temperature.  As the temp. difference diminishes, the effectiveness of the jet stream(s) diminishes and you get ridges of cold air pushing as far south as the equator, and hot troughs moving much warmer air than ususal into the Arctic, resulting in surface melting of Greenland, meltwater lakes expanding all across the Arctic, melting permafrost, heating of northern oceans, etc.  Heat drives all weather.

More current, the Cutter vaccine would cure polio, thalidomide, a sedative, was prescribed for anxiety and morning sickness. text:
We are in the most alarming situation that has ever occurred in human history, but we cannot be alarmists.  "Alarmist" is a bad word, because we call “alarmists” the fools and ignorants that promote Man-Made-Global-Warming.  Universities are a shame, not just the students, who maybe can be easily fooled. PhD professors and PhD researchers claiming that we all shoud go vegans because cow farts produce Global Warming and many other nonsense.  Are they idiots? Even NASA and NOOA are a real huge shame.

BIG ICE AGE
The easiest and simplest, understandable way you can explain the BIG ICE AGE to your family, friends and to everyone you find on your way and that does not require any science background, not even basic science, is the following: 

Man-made-global-warming is nonsense.  CO2 is not a pollutant.  CO2 is food for plants, food for life, food for happiness.  CO2 is really good for every living thing on Earth.

The Sun manages the Earth’s climate.  The Sun creates the Earth’s climate.  

As we know, the Sun has a cycle of 11 years on average and as its activity increases, so does the number of spots on its surface.  The action of the Sun reaches the entire Solar System.  It reaches the Earth, which is mainly oceans.  There in the oceans, the Earth’s climate will finish cooking. 

But the Earth has the Moon, so the action of the Sun that reaches the Earth is modified and modulated by the presence of the Moon.

The Moon has several cycles, of which, for now, we are interested in two of them.
The synodic cycle, from New Moon to New Moon and the metonic cycle. 

This metonic cycle is named after Meton, a very wise guy who lived in Greece 500 years before Christ.  He realized that 235 lunations, i.e., 235 synodic cycles, were equivalent to 19 years, with an accuracy of less than two and a half hours. Very wise Meton.

This means that if on July 16, 2019 there is Full Moon, then in the year 2000 (19 years before), as well as in the year 2038 (19 years later), there is also Full Moon on July 16.

Then we have a solar cycle of 11 years and we have a lunar cycle of 19 years.  If we multiply 11x19, we now have a cycle of 209 years composed of the action of the Sun and the way in which this action is modified and modulated by the presence of the Moon.  
 
At the peak of each eleven year solar cycle, its magnetic poles will exchange places. The north magnetic pole goes to the South and the south magnetic pole goes to the North.  So, the complete solar cycle is actually 22 years.

And, then again: 22x19=418.  Two hundred years ago, the Dalton Minimum occurred and four hundred years ago the Maunder Minimum, the Little Ice Age, occurred.  As they say, we have these two trains arriving at the same time. 

Let's talk a little about History.  We currently use the Gregorian Calendar, a true masterpiece.  It has an error of one day every 3,333 years.  The Mayans had a slightly more precise calendar, an error of one day every 5,000 years.
We all understand the Gregorian Calendar.  Anyone can say how many days will it take for his next birthday or for Christmas.  The Mayan Calendar was understood only by priests.

The Mayans recorded important astronomical, political and social events on stone columns or Stelae and on the upper part of the Stela, they recorded the date of the Long Count in which the event had taken place.  The Long Count was a downward count and would have started 3,114 years before Christ, time in which, according to historians, there were no Mayans. 

A very clever english guy named Thompson, based solely on Stelae that recorded astronomical events, found the correlation between the Long Count and the Gregorian Calendar.  The end of the Long Count indicated the death of the Fifth Sun. 

The Fifth Sun is the one we see every day flying high in the sky.  The Long Count ended on December 21, 2012.

John Casey very accurately, almost exactly, said that the current “solar hibernation” had begun at the beginning of the year 2013.
 
The Mayans were dedicated to study Astronomy several centuries.  Because of the rudimentary nature of their methods, it is very difficult that they could reach the knowledge of the Long Count with complete accuracy.  I think this is a much older knowledge that the Mayans received and preserved. 

Of all the Grand Solar Minima that have occurred in the last millennia, none is comparable to the current one.  This one will be very much worse and very much longer. it will last hundreds of years. Maybe, thousands of years.

We will not enter in the future in a regular Grand Solar Minimun or in a Mini Ice Age.  Since December 21, 2012 we are in the biggest Grand Solar Minimun ever.  A real an long lasting BIG ICE AGE.

Valentina Zharkova, that brilliant and lovely lady, said last year that next Solar Cycle 25  will be very weak and will last only eight years.  This Cycle 25 will begin later this year or early 2020.  In her recently published paper she says: “Substantial temperature decrease are expected during the grand minima ... whose magnitude can not be yet predicted”.

Now NASA says that Cycle 25 will be “the weakest of the past 200 years”.  Yeah, finally they noticed. Good boys. It will begin in April 2020 and will last 11 years. That is OK, but NASA has been cheating everyone and playing games with the man-made-global-warming nonsense, for too many years. 

So, at the beginning of year 2024, the Solar Cycle 25 will be at it's weak peak.  From now, until 2024, the climate chaos will be growing faster and faster.  After that, we will be in a free fall, going deeper into the BIG ICE AGE.

I want to analyze the effects of the other Moon cycles.  The anomalistic cycle, from apogee to apogee, wich precesses and makes a complete round in 08.75 years and the draconic cycle, that involves the ascending and descending lunar nodes, which precesses and takes 18.60 years to make a complete round. 

More at: manuelesbri.com

text:
Crazy is that the North Pole got within a hair's breadth of reaching the melting point of ice last year.  Crazy is that Canada had a 117 degree day.  Crazy is 122 degrees in Northern California and 130 degrees in Death Valley.  Crazy is that the average humidity of the air is now 7% greater, CO2 is 48% higher, methane is more than 110% greater, O2 is lower by 0.7%, and N2O is up by nearly 125%. .... all since 1750 and most of the change has come in the last 75 years.
Crazy is that Greenland is losing over 200 billion tons of ice and Antarctica is losing over 60 billion tons of ice ......... per year.  Crazy is that almost all of the tropical glaciers are gone.  Crazy is that 80% of the glaciers in Glacier National Park are gone and all of the rest are rapidly shrinking. It's now almost certain that the contiguous US will lose ALL of it's glaciers within a few decades.  That is just SOME of the "CRAZY".

text: @julesdingle  Yes, I understand that some charts are based on newer technologies that did not exist over the years that the temperature was fluctuating to previous highs and lows.  However, to use those charts as proof of temperatures rising above normal is deceptive and unscientific.  There are many other temperature records such as tree ring and ice core data that are able to show that we have had highs and lows throughout time and that we are simply experiencing one of those normal fluctuations.  Yes, man does have an effect on the environment and that needs to be addressed, but with proper attribution as to the effect we are causing rather than the blanket reason of global climate change.  Pollution must be curtailed, especially in countries like China and India where the rivers flow orange.  We also have to stop our attitude that we must ignore land to bring it back to a natural state.  This has caused massive desertification of land due to lack of removal of overgrowth.  There was a time when herds of Buffalo grazed the grasslands and kept them fertile.  Those herds are no longer there yet we do not allow cattle grazing that would keep the land healthy.  As a result dead grass builds up and seeds for fresh growth cannot take root.  Sometimes man must be careful how they intervene.

text:
​ @Offgridnut  Oh come on, this old ridiculous argument. Honestly, do you think that the climate scientists would have not noticed that if it were true? Do you think they are just a bunch of idiots paid (not enough!) by the governments? 
Let's be logical for a second, and tell me what's more likely to you:
1) the climate scientists are either stupid or liars.
2) there is point you didn't get.

If you think point 2) is the most likely (and you should!), then do some research to understand why CO2 emissions matter!

I'll help you with this one, but please stop believing all the clickbait stuff from youtube in the future....

We as humans are responsible for accumulated CO2 emissions that rose CO2 levels in the atmosphere from 280 ppm to 415 ppm. It is therefore much more that 1%. Emissions at a time t are irrelevant, the thing is that we emitted CO2 over time that wasn't (fully) compensated by an increase of CO2 sinks --> we are accumulating CO2 in the atmosphere.


As an example (not exact numbers!), even if we are emitting  only 1% more CO2 each year, if it's not compensated by a 1% increase of CO2 sinks it will just accumulate in the atmosphere over time... That's what happened since the industrial revolution  (but the increase is not linear but exponential, at least at the beginning). The greenhouse gas effect is dependent on the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere, not on the emissions. An analogy could be a bath (atmosphere) with water in (CO2 emissions) and water out (CO2 sinks). If the sum of sources = the sum of sinks, the water level (CO2 concentration) stays the same. If we increase water in (open more the tap), the level of water will rise over time! Even if we just open a little more! :)

Hope you got the broad picture.

Offgridnut

Really? Where did you get that from? It plays a role, indeed. But the Earth system is much more complex than that.

Are you referring to the dire predictions made by some JOURNALISTS? Or are you just repeating the idiotic arguments of some conspiracy theorists you watched on youtube?

"Maybe it is more complex than we are currently allowing with the modeling."
You have NO clue how complex the models are.

"Saying you are a climate scientist does not make it so"
If you're able to find crappy information on the internet, you are also able to google my name (I'm not hiding it!).

"If you are as you claim you should be able to address my concerns about CMIP6 vs CMIP5."
First, climate science isn't only about modeling. I'm not a modeler, although I'm able to get the broad picture of what they're doing. And you shouldn't be "concerned" about CIMP5 or 6, the modelers involved in this inter-comparison know what they're doing and the outcome stays the same! Of course, the forecast for the 21st century depends a lot on our future CO2 emissions pathway... nothing new!

Why don't you just read what scientists do and find instead of just bashing them? Do you also question the diagnostics of your GP, do you criticize your dentist? If you don't understand something, just look it up on the net! But don't start with youtube... :)
author: Christophe Espic
Offgridnut

text:
​ @Offgridnut  "This appeal to authority is nauseating." 
It's not an appeal to authority, it's just about asking to understand the facts and the possible outcomes described by the scientists.

"Of course I question my GP. My dentist is not omniscient. "
I was hoping for such an answer, because it's fine to question diagnostics. But if you ask 9 doctors and they all give you the same diagnostic, do you really think it's reasonable/meaningful to ask for a tenth advice? And if you really do so and ask a physicist for a health diagnostic and he has a different opinion, will you trust him over the 9 medical doctors??? That's exactly how some people see the 97% "consensus". And you explain that, they might even come with sth like "the scientists also believed the Earth was flat". But here is the BIG difference: it was NOT based on EVIDENCE!

For you other point, I won't talk about them as it's very easy to make your own opinion by checking some information on the net (e.g. the reason why CO2 kept increasing during the lockdowns, it's a very easy answer).

If you come to scientists with questions without just trying to prove them wrong (just trying to UNDERSTAND things), they will for sure try to explain. I never said we are always right, it's a science and there are always changes (especially with this topic :)) and new things to learn. Science is never settled, but the more we observe, measure and simulate the more we understand. FYI, the predictions from the climate scientists were usually too optimistic... I'm not talking about the ones from the journalists! I'm neither an activist, nor an alarmist. However, when I'm watching such videos and reading the comment sections, I become pessimistic. Cause yes, many behavioral changes are needed, and the more we wait the more drastic the required modifications (hope you understand my English, not sure this sentence is really meaningful to you).

author: john Chandler

text:
@john Chandler  The issue is not the total quantity of carbon in the Earth's sinks, but rather the rate of release in CO2 and methane. The Earth has the capacity to sequester carbon released as these gases and has been sequestering faster than these gases are released. Even at the present 400 ppm by volume, the level of CO2 is not optimum for plants. 800 ppmv to 1600 ppmv would be about optimum.
During the last ice age that ended about 12,000 years ago, the CO2 level dropped perilously low for plants and thus for all life on Earth. Below 150 ppmv plant life dies off and if much lower, all plant life would become extinct. 
Leonard Beadle in his book The inland waters of tropical Africa reported sand dunes under the Congo rain forest, indicating that at some time in the past the rain forest had died off. The level of CO2 during a previous ice age may have been too low for the trees in the Congo Basin.
Entering the next ice age with elevated CO2 would provide a safety cushion.
Related evidence of the impact of low atmospheric CO2 during ice ages: Evolution of C4 plants: a new hypothesis for an interaction of CO2 and water relations mediated by plant hydraulics, Osborne, and Sack, 2012
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3248710/

text:
GRETA THUNBERG IS A SHILL FOR THE GREEN INDUSTRY AND THEIR GOVERNMENT AGENDA !
Not one prediction or model of any Climate Alarmist has come to fruition without manipulation of Historical Data
THE CLIMATE ALARMIST 97% LIE !!!!
The 97% statistic that all Climate Scientist agree Man is primarily responsible for Anthropogenic Global Warming first appeared in 2009 in a study by the University of Illinois master student Kendall Zimmerman and her advisor Peter Doran. It was a two-question survey and only 5% of the people who answered a little over 150 were actual Climate Scientists. The 97% comes from an even smaller sub-set of 79 people who were self-professed Climate Scientists with 50% of their research being conducted on the subject of Climate Change. So that 97% figure originally came from 79 Scientists who agreed that the Earth’s temperature has risen since the 1800s and that Humans are likely a contributing factor. People used this Number and ran with it. When the evidence was running a little thin and people started questioning it in 2013 Australian blogger John Cook and some of his buddies reviewed some abstracts of peer-reviewed papers published between 1991 to 2011. What were his findings?: Coincidently that exactly 97% of Scientists either explicitly or implicitly made the assertion that Humans were somewhat responsible for warming not even Climate Change, BUT WARMING, his work was debunked as CRAP in Science and Education I August 2013. For example, David R Legates ( a professor at the University of Delaware and former director of it’s Center for Climatic Research) and three coauthors reviewed the same papers as did Mr. Cook and found “ only 41 papers—0.3 percent of all 11,944 abstracts or 1.o percent of the 4,014 expressing an opinion, and not 97.1 percent--- had been found to endorse” the claim that human Activity is causing most of the current warming. Elsewhere, climate scientists including Craig Idso, Nicola Scafetta, Nir J. Shaviv and Nils-Axel Morner. I really feel sorry and sad for you and your view of life in general.  You know, none of us are perfect. We are all sinners and but for the GRACE of God, none of us would have any hope. My Mum, always telling me, "Stop working so hard, caring, loving and doing so much for others.  Put yourself first for once!!  All I could reply was, "I don't know how." That was my life, I actually had a great deal of Love to give.  It was a TOTAL Joy to me.  It kept me strong with my feet solidly on the ground.  I actually did see lots of joy and Love in the world because I shared it with others. I have my opinions, mainly coloured by my family's experience of living under a COMMUNIST regime, being nearly deported to the Gulags in Sibera in  railway cattle trucks.  You know what our Sin was? We owned some property which we achieved through hard work!!  We managed to escape just in time before they were coming to collect us to send us on our way to a Death sentence. 
Our lives have been filled with hard work and gratefulness for being able to live in FREEDOM. How long this FREEDOM will last, who knows, if the SOCIALIST/MARXIST/COMMUNISTS have their way!!   The things you about our food and other essential items we need every day being laced with poisonous substances are right. But, what can be done about?!  Most people know about these things and all you can do is read the labels and try to avoid what you know is harmful.  It is difficult, but doable.  I also take certain vitamin supplements which I feel I am not getting from the food I consume.  Perhaps you can try that too plus some Fish oil capsules. Magnesium is also very good. When we don't get the necessary vitamins from our food, our health and the feeling of wellbeing can go downhill very quickly.  Perhaps you need some guidance about this matter.
