We are all human and we all go through suffering throughout our lives, but you can either let it make you or break you.  In the end, it rests on each one of us individually and it is called Perssonal responsibility. 
I don't know if I have helped you in any way but I hope so. There are SO many places you could go to for help and so many kindhearted people who would help you but you just have to reach out.
Like I said, the world isn't totally evil, there is the good amongst the bad.
Truly WISHING you all the best!!

GRETA THUNBERG IS A SHILL FOR THE GREEN INDUSTRY AND THEIR GOVERNMENT AGENDA !
Not one prediction or model of any Climate Alarmist has come to fruition without manipulation of Historical Data
THE CLIMATE ALARMIST 97% LIE !!!!
The 97% statistic that all Climate Scientist agree Man is primarily responsible for Anthropogenic Global Warming first appeared in 2009 in a study by the University of Illinois master student Kendall Zimmerman and her advisor Peter Doran. It was a two-question survey and only 5% of the people who answered a little over 150 were actual Climate Scientists. The 97% comes from an even smaller sub-set of 79 people who were self-professed Climate Scientists with 50% of their research being conducted on the subject of Climate Change. So that 97% figure originally came from 79 Scientists who agreed that the Earth’s temperature has risen since the 1800s and that Humans are likely a contributing factor. People used this Number and ran with it. When the evidence was running a little thin and people started questioning it in 2013 Australian blogger John Cook and some of his buddies reviewed some abstracts of peer-reviewed papers published between 1991 to 2011. What were his findings?: Coincidently that exactly 97% of Scientists either explicitly or implicitly made the assertion that Humans were somewhat responsible for warming not even Climate Change, BUT WARMING, his work was debunked as CRAP in Science and Education I August 2013. For example, David R Legates ( a professor at the University of Delaware and former director of it’s Center for Climatic Research) and three coauthors reviewed the same papers as did Mr. Cook and found “ only 41 papers—0.3 percent of all 11,944 abstracts or 1.o percent of the 4,014 expressing an opinion, and not 97.1 percent--- had been found to endorse” the claim that human Activity is causing most of the current warming. Elsewhere, climate scientists including Craig Idso, Nicola Scafetta, Nir J. Shaviv and Nils-Axel Morner. text: The averages and the highs/lows don't tell the story of what is happening. More granularity of data is needed.  The seasonal periods of warm temperature are lasting longer and over a wider area, even though the peaks may have only moved slightly. Most weather reporting just gives you high and low temps. It's also taking longer (more hours) on a given day or time period (days or weeks) to get cold but the cold weather is more intense and severe and doesn't last as long, or may last longer (hence the new term 'climate change'.)  But things are more erratic.  Precipitation patterns are affected also. But it's easy to say 'so what'. If you go back to wherever you grew up (and you're over 50) and check out the weather for a year,  no one can deny something is happening.

text:
0:50
Careful. While it's true that it does go up and down over the years, the overall trend is upwards. That is what climate change is referring to. If you take the data point from 1979 and data point for 2020 and draw a straight line between them, that will be a rough approximation for the average global temperature over those years. The slope of that line that you get is upwards, meaning the global temperature on average is increasing. Some years it will go up a little, and some years it will go down a little, but the average is going up. 

One way to think of it is like reading a scale to measure your weight. On a cheap scale, some days you'll be a certain weight, and then others you might be 0.1 lbs heavier, and then other days you might be 0.1 lbs lighter, and let's say you keep a diary of each of those measurements over the course of 10 years. If you do that, some days you'll weigh a little less, and some days you'll weigh a little more, but if the average weight measurement has increased over those 10 years, then you've gaining weight.

text:
@Mike Oz  Earth absorbs energy from sunlight, but as the surface warms, it also emits energy in the form of infrared radiation (which we know of as heat) out into space. Water vapor and CO2, however, act like a cap, making it more difficult for Earth to get rid of this energy. Without gases like these to absorb the energy, our planet’s average surface temperature would have been near zero degrees Fahrenheit.

About 99 percent of the atmosphere is made of oxygen and nitrogen, which cannot absorb the infrared radiation the Earth emits. Of the remaining 1 percent, the main molecules that can absorb infrared radiation are CO2 and water vapor, because their atoms are able to vibrate in just the right way to absorb the energy that the Earth gives off. After these gases absorb the energy, they emit half of it back to Earth and half of it into space, trapping some of the heat within the atmosphere. This trapping of heat is what we call the greenhouse effect. Because of the greenhouse effect created by these trace gases, the average temperature of the Earth is around 15˚C, or 59˚F, which allows for life to exist.

CO2 makes up only about 0.04% of the atmosphere, and water vapor can vary from 0 to 4%. But while water vapor is the dominant greenhouse gas in our atmosphere, it has “windows” that allow some of the infrared energy to escape without being absorbed. In addition, water vapor is concentrated lower in the atmosphere, whereas CO2 mixes well all the way to about 50 kilometers up. The higher the greenhouse gas, the more effective it is at trapping heat from the Earth’s surface.

The burning of fossil fuels affects the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere. Before the industrial revolution, the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere was about 288 ppm. We have now reached about 414 ppm, so we are on the way to doubling the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere by the end of this century. Scientists say that if CO2 doubles, it could raise the average global temperature of the Earth between two and five degrees Celsius. We are already increasing the amount of energy that bounces back to the Earth. Because of the greenhouse effect, this is causing global warming with its many destructive impacts.

Both water vapor and CO2 are responsible for global warming, and once we increase the CO2 in the atmosphere, the oceans warm up, which inevitably triggers an increase in water vapor. But while we have no way to control water vapor, we can control CO2. And because we are increasing the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere by continuing to burn fossil fuels, even in relatively small amounts compared to the entire mass of the atmosphere, we are disturbing the entire heat balance of the planet.

text:
@-Yttrium-  It wasn't a trend, it was a single data point. He picked a low data point then compared it to the average of late last century. That's not how trends are measured. That's called cherry picking.

And it wasn't over a century, the average was take between 1991 and 2000.
author: Simon Harris

text: @Simon Harris  "It was hotter over the last 2-3 yearsm lets not cherry pick" Meaning he understood the earth was warmer by 0.3 or 0.4 degrees in 2020 and 2016 for example. You're just misrepresenting his arguments despite him explicitly stating that he understood that it was a single datapoint. The graph is also a tool to measure trends, plotting temparature across a normalisation like that. You're trying to be right for the wrong reasons. Climate change is probaly real, your arguments are utter garbage.
author: -Yttrium-

text: @-Yttrium-  The point is, looking at single data points is pointless. This is how science deniers pull the wool over the eyes of those who are foolish enough to believe them. January was unusually cold That's the only point he's made here. He cherry picked out one single outlying data point, then used that as the basis of his conclusion. Anyone with even the most basic understanding of science knows why this is wrong, bordering on dishonest. He could have used January last year, and the increase would have been 5 times higher. If he's going to to pick the lowest data point as a comparison, then he should compare it to the lowest point from 1991-2000, which was -0.6, giving a change of 0.72 degrees.
author: Simon Harris

text: @Simon Harris  No, you just suffer from confirmation bias and you dont understand the video's argument. He simply wasn't cherrypicking. He just doesn't think a 0.4 increase over the average temparature from 1980 to 2020 is problematic. Which is wrong for other reasons that require actual knowlege. You've also proven that you dont know how to read a chart. Its already normalised. You pick zero as your baseline as that's the average temparature. If you pick the first datapoint to compare against then you're literally making the exact same mistake you accuse him off. But, again, he at least understood that you should look at the chart and not the first or last datapoint.
author: -Yttrium-

text: @-Yttrium-  You're the one who thought the average was over a century, not me. You're the one who claimed 0.12c was a trend rather than a data point, not me.  And Andrew is the one basing his argument on s single data point, not me. You couldn't be more wrong if you tried.
author: Simon Harris

text:

The little ice age of the 17th and 18th centuries AD and of the 6th and 7th centuries AD were on the other hand a nightmare for especially people living in the Northern Hemisphere. 

The warmer the more arable land becomes a available for cultivation,  less pandemics, the more plants and trees etc. We are presently  not even close to the warm temperatures of the warm period of the Middle Ages.

"The journal 'Climatic Change' was created in 1977 (and is still published today).  The IPCC was formed in 1988, and of course the 'CC' is 'climate change', not 'global warming'. We can still use both terms, depending on what we are referring to. There is no trick, no magic behind this.

THE CLIMATE ALARMIST 97% LIE !!!!
The 97% statistic that all Climate Scientist agree Man is primarily responsible for Anthropogenic Global Warming first appeared in 2009 in a study by the University of Illinois master student Kendall Zimmerman and her advisor Peter Doran. It was a two-question survey and only 5% of the people who answered a little over 150 were actual Climate Scientists. The 97% comes from an even smaller sub-set of 79 people who were self-professed Climate Scientists with 50% of their research being conducted on the subject of Climate Change. So that 97% figure originally came from 79 Scientists who agreed that the Earth’s temperature has risen since the 1800s and that Humans are likely a contributing factor. People used this Number and ran with it. When the evidence was running a little thin and people started questioning it in 2013 Australian blogger John Cook and some of his buddies reviewed some abstracts of peer-reviewed papers published between 1991 to 2011. What were his findings?: Coincidently that exactly 97% of Scientists either explicitly or implicitly made the assertion that Humans were somewhat responsible for warming not even Climate Change, BUT WARMING, his work was debunked as CRAP in Science and Education I August 2013. For example, David R Legates ( a professor at the University of Delaware and former director of it’s Center for Climatic Research) and three coauthors reviewed the same papers as did Mr. Cook and found “ only 41 papers—0.3 percent of all 11,944 abstracts or 1.o percent of the 4,014 expressing an opinion, and not 97.1 percent--- had been found to endorse” the claim that human Activity is causing most of the current warming. Elsewhere, climate scientists including Craig Idso, Nicola Scafetta, Nir J. Shaviv and Nils-Axel Morner. Financial benefits will indeed follow but instead of only landing in the pockets of the rich and powerful it will be a more even and organic distribution. Carbon emissions will still be reduced regardless of whether they are having an impact on temperature and in a couple of decades we will be able to see if this really does make a difference and in the meantime we will be making a more sincere effort to improve all of our lives rather than signing up for some get (other people) rich quick scheme masquerading as climate crisis.

text:
Acidic rain is a real thing tho. 
Sulphur gases in the atmosphere causes h2so4 (sulphuric acid) to form in clouds, and it rains down, making the ground more acidic. 
Happens for example during volcanic eruptions.

Pollution is a real scary thing with real scary consequences. But the carbon thing has been way exaggerated in my opinion
Plants need carbon dioxide to survive, they thrive with more of it. But toxic pollution actually kills animals and plants.
Acidic rain makes the ground unable to support plant life which would starve animals. And deforestation also does the same thing. 

Actually sustainable tree/hemp farming would do wonders for this world.

My main concern is that all these models are build on just 150 - 180 years of recorded history.  How accurate are these models compared to 1000 (15-18%) years, 5000(3-3.6%) years, 10000 (1.5-1.8%). I am quite sure there are still a quite a few natural factors that we are unaware of that also play a roll in the global temperature.
How many colder periods (ice ages) did we have in history?
   What was the temperature ranges during those periods?
   How long did they last?
   What caused them to end?
How many warmer periods (global warming) did we have in history?
   What was the temperature ranges during those periods?
   How long did they last?
   What caused them to end?

Obvious from the questions above is that I believe global warning and ice ages are naturally occurring cycles which runs across a period of time in succession. It does not require in input from us. We might be able to increase / decrease it (to what extend is questionable).

text:
When I was in college at Penn State in the early 70's, I remember a class I sat in where the professor was talking about the path that carbon took between the time that it was absorbed until it showed up as cellulose.  The experiment was to expose a leaf to C14 as CO2, then fix the leaf and analyze where the C14 was.

They started at 5 minutes.  C14 was EVERYWHERE.  So they cut the time in half and repeated the experiment.  Again C14 was EVERYWHERE.  So they cut the time in half AGAIN.  This went on for a number of repetitions.  It was not until the exposure time was down to the microseconds that they were able to track the steps that carbon dioxide took between absorption and showing up as cellulose.  In the space of one or two microseconds carbon went from absorption to cellulose through about a hundred different stages.  In a few microseconds!!

It suddenly hit me like a thunderclap what that meant.  It was the AVAILABILITY of CO2 that was the limiting factor for the growth of plants.  As a proof of that for the last half century, I have watched as the slow increase of CO2 in the atmosphere was followed by a monumental increase in the harvests in the world of FOOD.  

The increase of CO2 is followed by about a year by huge increases in food production WORLDWIDE.

On the day of judgment climate alarmists will have to answer for why they pressed for a kind of false science that worked toward worldwide starvation.

from IBD: If they were honest, the climate alarmists would admit that they are not working feverishly to hold down global temperatures — they would acknowledge that they are instead consumed with the goal of holding down capitalism and establishing a global welfare state.

Have doubts? Then listen to the words of former United Nations climate official Ottmar Edenhofer:

“One has to free oneself from the illusion that international climate policy is environmental policy. This has almost nothing to do with the environmental policy anymore, with problems such as deforestation or the ozone hole,” said Edenhofer, who co-chaired the U.N.’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change working group on Mitigation of Climate Change from 2008 to 2015.

So what is the goal of environmental policy?

“We redistribute de facto the world’s wealth by climate policy,” said Edenhofer.

For those who want to believe that maybe Edenhofer just misspoke and doesn’t really mean that, consider that a little more than five years ago he also said that “the next world climate summit in Cancun is actually an economy summit during which the distribution of the world’s resources will be negotiated.”

Mad as they are, Edenhofer’s comments are nevertheless consistent with other alarmists who have spilled the movement’s dirty secret. Last year, Christiana Figueres, executive secretary of U.N.’s Framework Convention on Climate Change, made a similar statement.

“This is the first time in the history of mankind that we are setting ourselves the task of intentionally, within a defined period of time, to change the economic development model that has been reigning for at least 150 years, since the Industrial Revolution,” she said in anticipation of last year’s Paris climate summit.

“This is probably the most difficult task we have ever given ourselves, which is to intentionally transform the economic development model for the first time in human history.”

The plan is to allow Third World countries to emit as much carbon dioxide as they wish — because, as Edenhofer said, “in order to get rich one has to burn coal, oil or gas” — while at the same time restricting emissions in advanced nations. This will, of course, choke economic growth in developed nations, but they deserve that fate as they “have basically expropriated the atmosphere of the world community,” he said. text:
Of course you  can question the science

National Climate Centre was not involved in climate research while Kininmonth was there. He runs a "skeptic" organisation out of his home with an official sounding fancy name. Nothing he says here amounts to an argument. It is just a recounting of facts and half-facts about some of the underlying processes which need to be taken into account and it serves no purpose other than to make it seem as if climate research is a lottery. He is also talking absolute rubbish about the correlation between CO2 and temp. It is not "weak" and the variability in temp across the globe is explicable in terms of ocean currents, land masses, the presence of ice and other geographical factors.

The earth is indeed rising in accordance with prediction. You can always take the upper range of predictions and lie on that basis I suppose. Even the older models from the 1970s were predominantly accurate and where there is inaccuracy they perform remarkably well when you adjust for discrepancies between assumed fluorocarbon levels, which changed due to policy driven reductions, and actual levels. Both the models'  predictions and hindcasting performance show them to be accurate. The "skeptics" never reveal that discrepancies between assumed CO2 output and actual output account for any discrepancies in prediction. The basic correlation between CO2 emissions and temp has been shown with quite a degree of confidence. It never ceases to amaze me how people will believe some chump making claims that publicly available data has somehow eluded climate scientists and they're all wrong, especially when a short consultation with an expert in the field can show exactly where the chump is mistaken or mis-leading.

text:
​ @Ivellios  "Yeah, a high level of CO2 causes the Earth to freeze. (what they were saying in the 70's) (Global Cooling)"
The scientists never said so, maybe just some MSM journalists! The reason why the Earth wasn't warming (40s till 70s) is well understood: POLLUTION. The rise in sulfate aerosols was largely due to the increase in industrial activities at the end of the second world war, and aerosols have a cooling effect! The effect was hiding the warming effect of greenhouse gases, the latter being already the main concern of climate scientists!
Thanks to the clean air acts introduced in Europe and North America, we reduced our emissions of sulfate aerosols, which is explains why the warming trend resumed.





"If you've ever bothered to look at the correlation of Earth's Temp and CO2 levels, you would have noticed that until humans invented fire, throughout all of history CO2 always trailed behind Temp".
Come on, the Earth system is much more complex than that! What if I tell you that the solar forcing can be the trigger (for example to get out of a glacial cycle) and then CO2 acts as a positive feedback and enhances the initial increase of temperature due to solar forcing? Temperature and CO2 levels are not totally independent! You should definitely read more about feedbacks, triggers, tipping points, ....

"Also if you've bothered to look at Earth's average Temp, you'd know that we're still 10 degrees below average. Technically we're in an Interglacial Period of an Ice Age"
Why comparing with a time when the Earth was totally different? Why would it be a proof that we can't be responsible for the recent warming? Have you looked at the totally different timescales? Do you think a fast transition would be favorable for the ecosystems and the civilisations?  Yeah, the Earth was hotter and DIFFERENT back then: so what? Does it diminish the current effects of global warming / climate change?

I think I'm gonna give up, you anyway think that scientists are paid to lie to you. I can tell you that I would have NEVER chosen this job if money was my first concern! I would have stuck with my engineering degree.

Have a nice evening (maybe day for you).

text:
@Mike Oz  Although Glaciologists measure year-to-year changes in glacier activity, it is the long term changes which provide the basis for statements such as "Global Glacier Recession Continues". Some Skeptics confuse these issues by cherry picking individual glaciers or by ignoring long term trends. Diversions such as these do not address the most important question of what is the real state of glaciers globally?

The answer is not only clear but it is definitive and based on the scientific literature. Globally glaciers are losing ice at an extensive rate (Figure 1). There are still situations in which glaciers gain or lose ice more than typical for one region or another but the long term trends are all the same, and about 90% of glaciers are shrinking worldwide

text:
@Walter Dayrit  Not true. The mammoth and several other species have died out at the end of the last ice age about 10000 years ago in a relatively short period of time. There weren't many humans, no modern civilisations, no planes, no cars. Or we can talk about the early medieval times when it was much warmer in the UK for example. The monks had vineyards in and around London. There are street names today that reflect that. It is very hard to imagine today, if you know that we normally have two weeks of real summer every year in the uk.
 Climate can change quite rapidly. I think it's our greatest arrogance to assume that we humans can cause the weather to change. We can make animals go instinct if we over hunt them, we can cut the trees in the Amazon forest, we can pollute the water with plastic but all these things won't change the climate. We simply are making our environment less healthy for ourselves. I think that we are making a huge mistake by concentrating on stopping the  naturally occurring climate change instead of trying to figure out ways to adapt to the changing climate. In the time of the first pharaohs in Egypt, the Sahara desert didn't exist. There was lush vegetation, trees, animals, rich land. It changed quite quickly in a relatively short period of time.
I think what we should concentrate on is, for example the migration of people from Africa and other places due to climate change. Back then if you had enough fighters, horses and determination you could save your nation by killing other tribes in your way. text:
@O Malley  Here an article from the Nature website:
They really were the Dark Ages

A massive volcanic eruption brought gloom to the post-Roman world.

Philip Ball 	 

		 

							 	 

￼An ancient eruption probably caused the most severe global dimming in the past two millennia.Getty

An enormous volcanic eruption in the sixth century seems to have triggered catastrophic global cooling, perhaps precipitating famine, cultural conflict and plague across the planet.

The theory offers an explanation for why historical records from the period make references to dimmer skies and a cooler climate. Documents from Ireland, for example, describe “a failure of bread” for a few years after 536 AD, and there are also accounts of summertime snow in China. 

The Byzantine historian Procopius wrote that in 536 “a most dread portent took place. For the sun gave forth its light without brightness… and it seemed exceedingly like the sun in eclipse, for the beams it shed were not clear.” 

Scientists have been studying evidence of this cold snap for more than 20 years. Tree rings from this time, for example, show that growth was slowed down by cold weather. The cause of these climate changes has been controversial. Now, however, it seems a volcano was to blame. 

Global cooling

Climate cooling is consistent with the idea that the atmosphere became shrouded in a haze of dust, as is known to happen after large volcanic eruptions. A dust veil, causing cooling and spectacular sunsets, appeared after the eruptions of Tambora in Indonesia in 1815, and of Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines in 1991.

“Any normal interpretation of the data would point to a volcanic origin,” says Keith Briffa, a palaeoclimatologist at the University of East Anglia in the UK and an author of the new study. But no one has previously been able to find clear evidence for that, leaving room for other theories. In particular, palaeoecologist Mike Baillie at Queen’s University in Belfast has proposed that the dust veil was created by a meteorite impact. 

Now Briffa and an international team of collaborators have found the characteristic fingerprint of a volcanic eruption in layers of ice in the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets, narrowly dated to around 533-536. They think that the eruption happened in 535, and that its effects were felt in the Northern Hemisphere in the following year, they write in the journal Geophysical Research Letters1.

This fingerprint takes the form of sulphate ions, formed from the sulphur dioxide released by volcanoes. Meteorite impacts do not tend to release sulphur into the atmosphere unless they happen to hit sulphur-rich minerals.

The fact that a sulphate layer can be seen not only in the northern but also the southern polar region implies that the eruption probably happened close to the Equator, so that its dust was dispersed all over the Earth. But the north bore the brunt of the climate effects – there’s no sign of cooling in geological records from New Zealand, for example.

Briffa explains that, although it’s not hard to spot such sulphate contamination of ice in principle, the hard part is constraining the dates of the layers enough to link them to the tightly dated tree-ring evidence of cooling, and to distinguish them from sulphate that came from smaller but nearer eruptions. This careful detective work was carried out by Bo Vinther and his co-workers at the University of Copenhagen, Denmark. 

'Most severe event'

The researchers say that the amount of sulphate they found implies that the eruption was even bigger than that of Tambora, perhaps releasing as much as 40% more dust. This, says Briffa, makes the event “the most severe volcanic cooling event in the Northern Hemisphere in the past 2,000 years”.

Some have suggested that its consequences were more dramatic than mere crop failure and overcast skies. Around 541, a plague pandemic rampaged from southern Asia to Denmark, wreaking havoc in the Byzantine Empire and possibly killing about 40% of the inhabitants of its capital Constantinople. 

ADVERTISEMENT

This so-called Justinian plague (after the Byzantine emperor Justinian I) might have been triggered by cold weather, during which it may be easier for plague-bearing fleas to reproduce. After hearing Baillie talk on the 536 AD event, British writer David Keys wrote a book in 1999 claiming that the cooling reshaped global history, playing a part in the rise of Islam and the migration of the Mongols. Keys proposed that the cooling was caused by an eruption of Krakatoa.

While historians think Keys’s case is tenuous, it now seems clear that a volcano did make itself felt around the world at that time. Now that the cause is clearer, says Briffa, “I think that historians may start to find more evidence of the event.”

text: Boy, did the host mangle the science. It's not 0.12 C over pre-industrial temperatures. It's 0.12 C over the average temperature from 1991-2020. We're a bit over 1C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures. The cool January is a result of the mid-strength la Nina, which appears to have peaked a couple of months ago. Interannual variability in the temperature record is caused by short term fluctuations in the climate system, like el Ninos and la Ninas, and other circulating or oscillating ocean/atmosphere systems. The scientist on wasn't much better.

text: There is proof of total global catastrophe every 12,000-13,000 years in the geological surveys, something that is never discussed.  People are stupid and willing to throw money at anything as long as it makes them feel good in the moment.  It only takes one large volcano erupting to send us into winter for several years, or one large solar flare interfering with our magnetic field to destroy most of the population.  I'm just waiting for Yellowstone to blow, or any of the numerous super volcanoes that exist, and are still active today.  There are SO many things that could interrupt the delicate balance of our planet and guess what?  There isn't ANYTHING you can do about it to change it.  Holding in a few farts isn't going to stop the billionaires from flying around in their private jets, or stop China and India from producing more pollution.  If you kill manufacturing jobs in the US, they just move overseas where THERE AREN'T REGULATIONS ON POLLUTION (or the rules aren't followed), leading to MORE POLLUTION.  Oh, also, 'magnetic north' or the north magnetic pole has traveled 50 miles in 2020, and continues to travel AWAY from Canada and Greenland.  In the year 2000, it was right off of the coast.  Now magnetic north is in the middle of the ocean, centered between Greenland, Canada, Alaska, and Russia.  The position of magnetic north affects the amount of ice that will melt as it travels further away from land and in to the sea.  This affects everything but we continue to ignore everything that is going on with our planet, and outside of our planet, blaming everything on 'carbon dioxide' because we humans are gullible morons.  If only people would take the time to do JUST A FEW HOURS of research.. Yeah, I know, I expect too much from the human race.

text: I don't believe Greta. The planet won't explode tomorrow if we don't go to zero carbon emissions by then. I was raised and still am a conservative. We cannot base our beliefs on climate change on a thermometer reading somewhere in Alabama. Anyone who says man is not damaging his own environment (in most cases, for profit) is an idiot. This planet has been raped by humans and would be much better off w/out us. I understand we can't make the switch overnight but I also understand that if we don't start changing our ways, sooner or later, future generations are going to suffer. Here on the east coast of America when the Wigan virus hit hard and most businesses were shut down the roads were practically empty. The difference in the color of the sky was almost immediate. The air smelled and even felt better. We're back to business as usual over here and the sky and air have followed suit. I tend to take life seriously only when I see it with my own eyes not by what some talking heads tell me. So you can sit back and make fun of indoctrinated little girls while you continue to contribute to turning the planet into a pisshole for your great-grandchildren. Or you can pull your heels out of the dirt and stop trying to discredit climate change and maybe start opening YOUR OWN EYES.

text: There are things called negative feedback mechanisms. When ice melts, it allows trees to grow therefore more Co2 can be absorbed, resulting in a decreasing global temperature. Hotter temperatures, leads to more evaporation and more cloud cover,  clouds are white  which would reflect solar radiation, lessening the global temperature. Take with a pinch of salt, I am not an expert, but the earth has wonderful ways to keep itself balanced. The warm water coral reefs will eventually die but cooler oceans nearer the Poles will soon be able to support more coral and marine life, resulting in more oxygen recycling.

text: @J Macdonald  The hole in the ozone layer was discovered in the 1950s before we’d started using CFCs. The ‘hole’ in the ozone layer was caused by volcanic gases from the volcanoes on Antarctica. The ozone layer is formed when UV light hits oxygen atoms and causes them to form long chain molecules that fall to Earth, oxygenating the land, sea and air. At night there is no ozone layer and a new one is formed during the day. The company that originally made the CFC coolant had its patent running out and competitors were getting their cheaper versions ready to flood the market. The company managed to find scientists to ‘prove’ the hole was caused by CFCs getting governments around the world to ban it, thus making their competitors stuff useless. The original company then brought out a new version later.

text:
GRETA THUNBERG IS A SHILL FOR THE GREEN INDUSTRY AND THEIR GOVERNMENT AGENDA !
Not one prediction or model of any Climate Alarmist has come to fruition without manipulation of Historical Data
THE CLIMATE ALARMIST 97% LIE !!!!
The 97% statistic that all Climate Scientist agree Man is primarily responsible for Anthropogenic Global Warming first appeared in 2009 in a study by the University of Illinois master student Kendall Zimmerman and her advisor Peter Doran. It was a two-question survey and only 5% of the people who answered a little over 150 were actual Climate Scientists. The 97% comes from an even smaller sub-set of 79 people who were self-professed Climate Scientists with 50% of their research being conducted on the subject of Climate Change. So that 97% figure originally came from 79 Scientists who agreed that the Earth’s temperature has risen since the 1800s and that Humans are likely a contributing factor. People used this Number and ran with it. When the evidence was running a little thin and people started questioning it in 2013 Australian blogger John Cook and some of his buddies reviewed some abstracts of peer-reviewed papers published between 1991 to 2011. What were his findings?: Coincidently that exactly 97% of Scientists either explicitly or implicitly made the assertion that Humans were somewhat responsible for warming not even Climate Change, BUT WARMING, his work was debunked as CRAP in Science and Education I August 2013. For example, David R Legates ( a professor at the University of Delaware and former director of it’s Center for Climatic Research) and three coauthors reviewed the same papers as did Mr. Cook and found “ only 41 papers—0.3 percent of all 11,944 abstracts or 1.o percent of the 4,014 expressing an opinion, and not 97.1 percent--- had been found to endorse” the claim that human Activity is causing most of the current warming. Elsewhere, climate scientists including Craig Idso, Nicola Scafetta, Nir J. Shaviv and Nils-Axel Morner. Whose research questions the alleged consensus, protested that Mr. Cook ignored or misrepresented their work. Professor legates peered reviewed paper debunking Cook:

text: @Red Terrier  I have seen the planet view from space and from a plane. And yes there is plenty of darkness a person can see. Humans have always been here, civilizations as big as ours or bigger have already existed in the past. We may leave our prints but we do not affect the natural cycles of this planet. They don't yet why Siberia is doing what it is doing, possible the rising of the warmer methane gas is causing the permafrost to melt but what's pushing it up? Pressure from the magma under those deep pockets? They do not know yet. I just know what I theorize it to be from common things happening around the world. It's logical to think it's the same thing affecting it in Siberia, which is the magma. Or maybe it's deep under ground water. Cause and effect can be created from opposite ends of the planet easily. Tsunamis have a way of doing that. We don't have the true answers yet to some of these things happening. But what I do know is humans are arrogant that way to think we can control or stop such things, and it's just as arrogant to think that we are able to cause such things way bigger than we are. Which some would say it's foolish to not think we can't. But I know we aren't melting the ice cap in antarctica, that's magma activity happening same as in yellowstone. Any of that sound familiar? Antarctica and Siberia familiar? All of Europe is sitting on a magma chamber. Washington also, which that is also moving closer to the surface. Tons of ancient writings and in what we consider mythology tell us these things have happened before. The hopi indian prophecy might be more accurate than we know, I think they say mother earth has passed thru 3 world's and we are coming into the 4th. With each new world the last is destroyed.  While scientist are saying things are speeding up, some think it's been happening in the last 100yrs and we are just coming to the end of that cycle. The dead sea is coming back to life, the change in the atlantic ocean currents could be part of that biblical prophecy. Right now it's underground fresh water causing the dead sea to replenish itself, but soon it might be the ocean currents that really bring life back to it as animals from land and water will follow the currents. These shifts in currents will push back on the fresh water rivers. Pushing them into places we haven't seen them in over 6000yrs or more. It's all connected to each other.even from opposite ends of the earth.

text:
@Edgar Poe  Whilst you have presented a great deal of information, much of it is false or based on beliefs drawn from mischievous posts....many of the Charismatic Religions i have encountered including the Creationists who post misinformation or  science which struggles to meet the scrutiny of peers... perhaps they are impatient to experience their own salvation through the Rapture......I will not challenge all of your announcements.....but I would gladly do so for a case of enlightenment...eg .from a recent NBC News Report "The Dead Sea is dying rapidly. The biblical body of water lying between Israel and Jordan is retreating by more than three feet a year, creating sinkholes that swallow up buildings and roads, and forcing the rich seaside landscape on which the tourism industry relies to fade into memory.
It is the saltiest sea on earth. Some experts believe it will be gone by 2050, while others say it will never fully disappear but survive at a fraction of its current size."
As for civilisations in the 'past' as large as our own currently...there is absolutely no evidence to support this only 'fairy' stories, biblical twists. I will accept the previous civilisations were advanced, populated and more advanced than we were taught at school. Indeed Eratosthenes of Cyrene calculated the circumference of a 'spherical' earth 250 BCE yet for many centuries the Western World were 'instructed' by religious 'Christian' zealots that the earth was flat......for the west it was a time noted as the Dark Ages yet for the East a time for mathematics and science. a time of enlightenment...I fear that the science deniers of 21st century are pursuing the folly of the past and procuring their own dark ages.
As for light seen from space may i refer you to  city-lights-from-space/#:~:text=It%20might%20surprise%20you%20to,are%20brighter%20than%20the%20stars. 
I will not question your right to believe what you wish...however please avail yourself to seek critical review of your own 'facts', where  they come from, how they have been challenged by peers, how some are presented by charlatans and snake charmers.....the one thing I will agree the ultimate survival of our planet is currently beyond our control...the  Sun will ultimately consume us, that incursion by other celestial bodies will cause catastrophic impacts, as they have done in the past. But as a survivor of 'dramatic' pollution by humans and the industrial revolution in the North of England....where sunlight was blocked by carbon ladened smog and children, myself included' taken to sun rooms to receive adequate artificial 'sunlight' to ensure optimal growth and development, where rivers had died from the poisonous waste of the woollen mills and the carbon 'fell' from the sky and covered the cream coloured Yorkshire stone with its blackness.. perhaps this is why the UK is more responsive to 'climate change' as a result of humans they have seen it first hand...ps I too have seen light from Towns and cities 3kms above the surface and also the illumination of the ignited gas on the flares stacks of oil rigs over Iraq.. I shall choose to accept peer evaluated science, well credentialed archeology, the power of mathematics but will always enjoy the romanticised and curiosity of mythology.....and sometimes we can fit them to reality.

text:
Status of COVID-19
As of 19 March 2020, COVID-19 is no longer considered to be a high consequence infectious disease (HCID) in the UK.

The 4 nations public health HCID group made an interim recommendation in January 2020 to classify COVID-19 as an HCID. This was based on consideration of the UK HCID criteria about the virus and the disease with information available during the early stages of the outbreak. Now that more is known about COVID-19, the public health bodies in the UK have reviewed the most up to date information about COVID-19 against the UK HCID criteria. They have determined that several features have now changed; in particular, more information is available about mortality rates (low overall), and there is now greater clinical awareness and a specific and sensitive laboratory test, the availability of which continues to increase.

The Advisory Committee on Dangerous Pathogens (ACDP) is also of the opinion that COVID-19 should no longer be classified as an HCID.

The need to have a national, coordinated response remains, but this is being met by the government’s COVID-19 response.

Cases of COVID-19 are no longer managed by HCID treatment centres only. All healthcare workers managing possible and confirmed cases should follow the updated national infection and prevention (IPC) guidance for COVID-19, which supersedes all previous IPC guidance for COVID-19. This guidance includes instructions about different personal protective equipment (PPE) ensembles that are appropriate for different clinical scenarios.

Definition of HCID
In the UK, a high consequence infectious disease (HCID) is defined according to the following criteria:

acute infectious disease
typically has a high case-fatality rate
may not have effective prophylaxis or treatment
often difficult to recognise and detect rapidly
ability to spread in the community and within healthcare settings
requires an enhanced individual, population and system response to ensure it is managed effectively, efficiently and safely
Classification of HCIDs
HCIDs are further divided into contact and airborne groups:

contact HCIDs are usually spread by direct contact with an infected patient or infected fluids, tissues and other materials, or by indirect contact with contaminated materials and fomites

airborne HCIDs are spread by respiratory droplets or aerosol transmission, in addition to contact routes of transmission

text:
More sun-spots mean increased solar output and vice-versa. The coldest part of the little ice-age was known as the Maunder Minimum in the mid 18th century, when there were no sun-spots for decades.
The greenhouse effect due to CO2 has plateaued; increasing the concentration will have no effect on climate.
author: Paul Jackson

text: @Paul Jackson  how is that the case?
author: Jorge Gonzalez

text:
@Jorge Gonzalez  1. Sunspots are areas of intense magnetic flux and arise when solar output is high. They appear dark, because they are slightly cooler than the surrounding photosphere, but overall solar output is increased.
2. Carbon Dioxide absorbs infra-red (IR) radiation from the surface of the Earth only at certain wavelengths and converts it to heat, contributing to the greenhouse effect.
It has been shown (by German Physicist Heinz Hug) that at the current level of CO2 in the atmosphere, about 400ppm, that these wavelengths are completely absorbed in the first 10 metres of atmosphere above the surface.
So increasing CO2 concentration will have no further effect, because all the IR radiation which can be absorbed by CO2, is already being absorbed, very close to the surface of the Earth.
author: Paul Jackson

text: @Paul Jackson  Interesting stuff. Thanks for the response

text:
The focus on those colder regions are the only way they have to measure how quickly glaciers are melting.  And, yes, satellite measurements are significant, since they can provide a more concise measurement of depletion.

Let me explain a little more in depth, and you'll understand why you're seeing what you think you're seeing.  Glacier ice is a huge reflector of the sun's heat.  If glaciers melt, the heat goes into the surrounding waters, which melts the glaciers even quicker, then even more of the sun's heat goes into the water...well, you see the cycle.  All that excess moisture, now in the ocean, starts to evaporate, and it must go somewhere (hence, all the flooding around the world, larger than normal snowfalls, and, yes, even snow in very unusual places).  That excess moisture in the air also tends to create more of a temperate climate around the center third of the earth...which may be why it hasn't felt that warm to you.

Climate change is a normal and cyclical event, which scientists are in total agreement about.  The controversy is whether man has sped up that natural process or not.  And the next leg of this wonderful adventure will be another ice age, so buckle up.

text: We'd be in a really big problem if it wasn't going up.  If you'd have listened to the guy being interviewed, who actually did know his stuff, the 300 year cold period know as The Little Ice Age (when people skated on the frozen solid Thames River each winter) is considered to have ended around 1880 or so.  As such the world started to warm again from that time, all before there was any material increase in CO2 levels (which really didn't increase till around 1960), just as it should.  At some point it'll do exactly what it has done for thousands of years, turn and trend downward again.

author: Terry Quarton

text:
@Terry Quarton  There is no agreed scientific consensus The Little Ice Age was due to volcanic activity.  That's just one theory, among many other hotly debated theories, and the one favored by climate alarmists as it suits their false narrative  the worlds climate is rather stable, other than when driven by some external forcing e.g, volcanos, human emissions.  They are so set on 'proving' the climate was rather stable prior to CO2 emission started rising they were even prepared to falsify headline UN reports (research Climategate i.e. Natures Trick).  Michael Mann DID pressure his colleagues to falsify the data for political and personal power reasons.
That the Little Ice Age was only a local rather than global event is also a popular theory pushed by the climate alarmists to dismiss the importance of The Little Ice Age.  There is now overwhelming solid scientific evidence The Little Ice Age was a global event, just the timing between the Northern and Southern hemispheres differed slightly.  Perfectly understandable as the two hemispheres operate as mostly two largely independent climate 'systems'.

text:
@Peter Johnson  There still is a hole in the ozone layer. As far as anyone can tell it's always been there. The interesting thing is that the majority of CFC usage was in the northern hemisphere. So why was the hole in the south? Did all the heavy CFCs drain to the bottom? And I won't even go into the insanely short baseline used for the panic.

However and in all seriousness the hole has quite a simple explanation once you understand the processes involved. Firstly ozone is created by certain light frequencies hitting the atmosphere. This means that ozone is created between the Tropics as that's where the effect is strongest. Light in the Antarctic is hitting at a very oblique angle and so doesn't create much ozone in the polar regions. This is evidenced at both poles. In the north the ozone from warmer climes mixes with the Arctic air and replenishes the ozone. However the south has the "Circumpolar Current", a "wall" of air that effectively almost prevents ozone from the lower latitudes reaching the southern polar region. Hence with little ozone created there and not much coming from the tropics the free chlorine in the atmosphere from Mount Erebus causes the hole. Compared to nature we are nothing. https://principia-scientific.com/antarctic-ozone-depletion-due-to-erebus-volcano-gas-emissions/

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1352231015304246

And there's also the absolutely amazing coincidence that the ozone hole panic and the rush to ban CFCs came just as the patents were running out and India was about to supply the world with much cheaper CFC refrigerants. Of course, India couldn't do that and guess who just happened to have a CFC replacement ready for the market? At a slightly increased price, of course.

text:
Want to know something sad? 2019 - when she made that little "speech" of hers - was my last year of college. And I was taking a Linguistics Class with a focus on Rhetoric. My professor was explaining to us the difference between Pathos, Ethos and Logos - which Pathos is an appeal to emotion to get people to feel pity or sorrow or fear, Ethos is an appeal to Community, and Logos is an appeal to Logic.
He used Two Speeches and had us cite which was using which - one was Greta, the other was Trump addressing the UN, taking a firm stance against China.

...The idiots in my Class thought that Greta was using Logos when she was obviously using Pathos - when they defended their position, they pointed out that Greta mentioned the people and animals that are effected by Climate Change. At which point I countered by saying, she made a general statement that this is assumed to be happening, without stating any statistics or evidence that it is...Greta's entire speech hinged upon idiots already wanting to believe her.

Needless to say, only one person was right in class that day, and my Professor acknowledged it...The rest of the class hated me for the rest of the semester, but it didn't change that I was right.

text: I just wonder, how is it that whenever these Co2 discussions start, there never is somebody mentioning the ongoing change in the gravitational field or weathering? Like we don't know if there is a link between the "warming" and the change in the poles. We do know though, weathering increases with raising temp. and does bind more Co2. At some point, weathering binds more Co2 than being produced and the next cold-period starts (we talk 9000year rhythm between warm/cold-periods, proven by ice drilling). So if we see an increase in temp. we should see more weathering, therefore I doubt that we accelerate the warming and even if we do, it should balance itself out by accelerated weathering. Btw. fun facts: 1. for almost 50% of earth's existence, the poles were not frozen over. 2. They look for another earthlike planet in the vast space, the perfect candidate would have up to +5°C avg. temp. Compared to our current avg. global temp.

text: @Hansi Reichardtsohn  no, that’s just silly. Natural planetary cycles don’t just “move heat around” the way you’re saying. 😂. You’re falsely trying to imply the planet doesn’t go through overall cooling and warming periods naturally, when we have plenty of evidence that it does and quite regularly. It’s always gaining and losing heat, not just moving it around. The sun’s activity changes sure, but the different types of cloud cover that forms at different elevations actually affects how much overall heat or energy the earth absorbs from the sun or reflects off in the first place. Planetary cycles are not “just” about moving heat around.

text:
@VM VS  As there are so many replies now under the original comment I'm not going to go back and try and find the context of your comment.  So just taking what you have written as a standalone comment (which I acknowledge may not do justice) ......
You don't need to "show me another side".  Everyone knows the 'other side', it has been thrust down our throats, other than a brief respite for covid paranoia, every day for years.  
Yes, mankind hasn't been harmonious with nature, and that why I'm a committed conservationist.  BUT, there is a VAST difference between being a committed active environmentalist, and political actors using CO2 to bring about radical social change that will do next to nothing for the environment.
You will not win hearts and minds describing anyone with a different perspective on the best way to tackle the very many environmental issues facing us as " arrogant, ignorant or complacent around the issue of ecosystem dislocation."  That's the typical response used by political motivated 'climate extremists'.  Anyone who doesn't fully subscribe to their narrow and often inexperienced view of the world lacks the supreme 'education', 'enlightenment', or 'intellect' they believe they uniquely possess.
Not subscribing to the CO2 paranoia is not "doing nothing".  In fact people like me believe it highly counterproductive as trillions of dollars are wasted on unproductive ventures where the money could be far better spent on issues that will have a very real and lasting impact on the environment.  Cleaning the plastic from the oceans, or diverting water inland in Australia to stop the environment have to compete with farming irrigators for a scare resource on the driest continent on earth are examples.   The environment will always loose in that last example, where our major inland river system come to a near stop full of toxic algae and suffocated dead fish by the millions due to lack of water flow.   But closing a coal fired power station 1000 kilometers away is somehow going to fix the problem.  It won't, it'll do NOTHING for the environment, and actually put the country into a less financial position to be able to do something.
The focus on CO2 is actually a highly unproductive and polarizing approach to addressing the environment.  It has virtually nothing to do with the environment.  It is all about re-engineering society and a power shift from the West to China.  Research who Maurice Strong was (called the farther of climate change).  Take the time to fully understand what occurred in 'Climategate' where UN reports were fudged to appease their 'political masters'.
A focus on C02 and the environment is just like a focus on vaccines for covid.  The focus to deal with covid should be action to address the level of obesity (over 40% of Americans) and all its associated lifestyle diseases.  That's why people are dying from an otherwise quite mild bug.  Society has become incredibly unhealthy, that is the problem.  Focus on a vaccine, is just power and people wanting to make money. Exactly the same as a focus on CO2 emissions thinking that's addressing the environment.   Suggest you read some of Bjorn Lomborg's thoughts on the matter.

text:
@Freedom is over sad  You really need to educate yourself.  There is a virtual army of scientists from many branches who spend years trying to reconstruct the temperatures from past periods.  There are unbroken historical temperature records going back to 1659 (The Central England Data Series), recorded historical events that could only happen with certain temperatures , tree ring analysis, carbon dating of tree remains from glaciers to determine tree/snow lines, etc, etc, etc.  But despite all this, while certain trends of when warming and cooling events occurred are pretty much agreed, the magnitude of those swings remains a point of some debate.  Well at least it has to be that way otherwise the current climate emergency narrative falls on its ear.   
For what it worth, based upon solid scientific studies e.g. historic tree lines in the European Alps and indisputable historical events e.g the settlement of Greenland, and subsequent abandonment due to deteriorating climatic conditions a couple generations latter, Hannibal crossing the Italian Alps with 37 elephants and 8000 horses to attack the Romans (a feat impossible today), I think its pretty clear periods in the past 2000 years were warmer than present.
